content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Update: this review got popular so I made it a bit more detailedFor some reason dismemberment is copy protected on the steam version and will not work via the in game console, also by default the game doesn't support all resolutions via the in game options.So to get around this we make a file called autoexec.cfg and put it in the gamedata/base folder. In the file write the following, (the autoexec file is read from bottom to top for some reason).seta r_mode -1seta r_customaspect 1seta r_customwidth 1920seta r_customheight 1080set g_sabermorerealistic 2set helpusobi 1Once that is done you should see it show up like this in the gamedata/base folderhttp://i.imgur.com/szG45Aj.png(notice how the Type for the autoexec shows up as CFG file and not a text file, this is also where you dump .pk3 files to get mods to run)This is my autoexec for reference, it has a few more tweaks and i play at a laptop resolution because im currently on a laptop.http://i.imgur.com/6YnU2M0.pngNow you can enjoy maximum dismemberment and the absolute best lightsaber combat in the history of video games at your desired resolution. I would suggest not touching the in game resolution settings while playing, the other options are fine though.One of my favorite games of all time, enjoy it the right way.

												For me this may be the Best Star wars game ever made, you really get the feeling you are in star wars, even that this game takes place a few years after star wars VI. the Storyline and Side missions are really great, and it's feels like it's an open world you are in. A round can be very long and fun (based on how fast you and your team are to clear the way and destroy the targets). For me the graphics are wonderful i normally  remap everything with HD texture but this game doesn't need it at all. It's wonderful and if your a star wars fan you wont regret you bought it.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Have you ever wanted to be a Jedi? The Force isn’t strong enough in real life for you to be one? Well then, this game is good enough to satisfy that need. If you never wanted to be one, then this game will show you its charm anyway and afterward, you’ll fall in the former category. Despite its outdated look,  the gameplay is engaging and the story has the SW charm to it. This game has the original trilogy’s atmosphere, but it has more action.  Despite its predecessor, the level design won’t get you lost and there is less linearity, as you can select your gender, race, lightsaber fighting style and its shape and choice you make in the (near)end, whether to stay in the light or give into the dark and the consequences feel strongly(the protagonists attitude changes, some die, some get hurt, everything is awesome). There are some great moments for a Star Wars fan, such as fighting alongside Chewbacca, force choking Boba Fett, or taking a station down with Wedge Antilles. 


Regular Jedi Business 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy™
By: F4rseeR




The gameplay involves lightsaber fighting(this is what made the Jedi Knight series famous) that inspired the combat of Blade Symphony, as there are many duels. Aside from those instances, chopping arms and heads of stormtroopers that actually can aim is really entertaining.  Jumping on walls, then on your adversaries is a good example of how fluid the combat can be. There are three types of force powers: light sided ones,  which involve sustaining health by healing and protection, and turning your enemies into allies, the universal ones like force push, pull, speed, sense and lightsaber throw and there are the dark sided ones, which are damaging and risky, as you’ll enter modes that strengthen you while draining your health, exposing yourself with force choke or force lightning, though the latter, when upgraded to its zenith, means pushing everyone out of the room while having bolts all over them.  You also have an arsenal of weapons to your disposal, that have primary and secondary types of firing. 


Time for one of us to become one with the Force 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy™
By: F4rseeR




The story has its charm, as you start up as a student and end up being a Jedi Knight, there are many iconic characters and there is Kyle Katarn, the hero of the other Jedi Knight games.  The plot isn’t really intriguing, but it has its mystery. 80% of the game you’ll be doing missions that don’t seem to be related to the plot, but more to being a Jedi, that is keeping the peace in the Galaxy. 


Come and get me 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy™
By: F4rseeR




The game last for about 8 hours, provided you tend to be alive most of the time. For Star Wars fans it’s a treat and some don’t exaggerate when they call it the best Star Wars game; while it’s a matter of taste, this game ends up on being on the favorites list. For newcomers, it’s enough to make them understand why people go crazy over Star Wars. The game isn’t complex, but is good enough to spend time with it and enjoy doing so.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
Lore-friendly & fun from start to finish // Recommended for Star Wars fans+ Voice acting is mostly passable, with a few notable exceptions+ Visuals, animations, and effects are decent for year of release, so it's hard to justify counting them against the game; they didn't necessarily age well, but certainly not to such a degree as to hold it back+ Movement and platforming feels smooth and organic; this is particularly evident when 'force jumping'+ Environmental puzzle elements are well-designed, and work well with the use of the player's core 'force abilities'+ Dark side/ Light side orientation can be chosen, but isn't necessarily influenced by dialogue, as in many other titles+ Audio design is ripped directly from the films, and does well to complement the final product+ Melee and FPS transition works seamlessly; both are fun in their own right, and neither serves to detract from the game's enjoyment+ Combat is both fun and engaging; this, clearly, was the primary focus of the developers, and the combat system is easily that which works best in the title+ Secret areas are available, offering tangible rewards for one's mission+ Controls are intuitive and adequately explained in the tutorial missions; however, there is seemingly no controller support to speak of+ Plot is nothing sensational, but it measures up fairly well to the rest of the franchise, and doesn't divorce itself from the established nuances of the Star Wars universe- Vehicle controls, notably turning, can prove a bit clunky in practice- Enemy AI is positively atrociousLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												Remember Jedi Outcast? With Kyle Katarn we needed to struggle through a couple of levels until we could, finally, get our hands on a lightsaber. Now, Jedi Academy completely skips these few levels. You are, already, a Jedi and in possession of a lightsaber. Make no mistake: the same array of shooting weapons are available, personally, however, I never used any.I liked this concept. In fact, at the beginning a few customisations are available: you can pick your race, the colour of your clothing and - most importantly - the colour of your lightsaber. Many missions can now be completed in the desired order but once you continue the main storyline it is, of course, the same old linear storytelling.The game runs on the same Quake 3 engine and - as already mentioned - has the same assortment of weapons available at your disposal. However, since it is soooooooo cool to wield lightsabers we now have the option to 1) have two lightsabers at the same time or 2) use the lightsaber staff Darth Maul had in Phantom Menace. Of course, the single lightsaber option is still available with the 3 stances already offered in Jedi Outcast.There is not much else to say about Jedi Academy. Fighting with lightsabers has never been cooler and the game heavily emphasizes this concept. The game gives us a long-lasting experience and I heard multiplayer is even better! Do note that enabling the widescreen option requires some tweaking - do head over to wsgf.org for the solution.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
TL;DRA classic game set in the classic universe. This is a must play not only for the Star Wars fans.+ Magnificent and balanced combat system+ Choose your style: single, dual, or a sabrestaff+ Variety of guns+ Use the Force, Jaden!+ The protagonist doesn't have to be a human :)+ Option of choosing between the light and the dark side+ Soundtrack+ MULTIPLAYER+ Tons of player-created content- Plot isn't an A+ material (but it's not bad by any means)REVIEWIt's a blast from the past – still fun after all these years. The game tells us the story of the Jedi struggling to prevent the Cultists from resurrecting Marka Ragnos – an ancient Dark Lord of the Sith.The protagonist, unlike in most of the games in the Jedi Knight series, is one of the Luke Skywalker's students named Jaden. One can choose race, gender, and appearance of the main character. What is more, the hero's lightsabre can be customised as well. Later on, there is also a possibility to choose either a single blade, dual blade, or a sabrestaff. Each of the weapons feature a different playstyle, animations, and moves. In addition to the elegant weapon(s) for a more civilised age, there are a few guns and explosives available.The lightsabre combat system is truly unique and works like charm. It is easy to learn and hard to master. It punishes the weak and empowers the strong, so to speak: it rewards well-timed blows and dodges as opposed to mindless mashing the buttons as fast as possible. Moreover, it is well-balanced: every playstyle is viable. Apart from fencing, a player can use a variety of Force powers which are divided into three categories: Neutral (e.g. Push), Light (e.g. Heal), and Dark (e.g. Lightning). In single player, a player can assign points to the Light and the Dark side powers (the Neutral ones grow as the story progresses). While single player is decent, the clue of the game is its multiplayer. I have put around 200 hours in the multiplayer alone and I definitely am looking forward for more. Despite the game being past its prime, it still has a small but devoted community. There also are myriads of mods, characters, maps, and other types of player-created content which further improve longevity of the game.Concluding, Jedi Academy still is one of the best Star Wars games in my opinion. I have yet to play a game with a more enjoyable and balanced combat system and I strongly recommend trying it out even today: it may look dated, but the core mechanics are timeless.P.S. Please check out my other reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/My curation page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FVABot/curation

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												It's probably fair to say that the single-player aspect of this game isn't as solid storywise as its predecessors (and I do recommend checking out the early incarnations of the Jedi Knight series) but the reason for playing this game is in the action and friends. LIGHTSABERS: You are able to choose between Single, Dual or Staff, which is a first for the series (only Single is available when you start the SP storyline. The others will become available later.)FORCE POWERS: You are able to pick and choose which ever powers are offered from both polarities of the Force. In SP you can pick any power at any time but MP is more restrictive -- forcing you to choose one side or the other. GUNS: Well, maybe not as exciting as the first two, but the some of the guns offered here are the sort of things that only the SW Universe offers and you'll be hard pressed to find similar items in other games. But what really takes the cake on this game is if you are able to play online with a great group of friends. You will spend countless hours with them. There is a community that has stood by this game throughout the years it has been around and I suspect they will be around for even longer. Much of the community functions in an RPG aspect where people will form their own groups and incorporate SW lore into their gatherings while other aspects of the community will focus on the skill of brandishing the lightsaber or Force. Even further, there are countless mods offered to further enhance gameplay and your experience.So yes! Buy and play this game. If you want to play this game however, you should do yourself the favor and play the previous games of the series so you are familiar with the storyline, lore and whatnot. It will make the experience much more rewarding once you arrive at this title. Aside from the hours Steam shows here, I've must of put in another thousand hours or so that are not shown. I have many memories of the good times I had playing. This is the game of my teenage years.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												I've spent over 10 000 hours playing this game during the past 12 years. It's safe to say that it has a lot of lasting power.The game sports a very intricate lightsaber system unlike any other since then. This is what lightsaber combat should be like in all Star Wars games. The player has full control over his/her attacks unlike modern button-mashers where you are lucky to have an overly simplified combo tree.In addition to a very well crafted lightsaber system it features a tremendous modding scene, much like any other IdTech 3 engine games. The active modders hang around at jkhub.org and are actively pushing out new models, weapons and maps. There are even some characters from The Force Awakens available.These alone should keep you playing for days.If you are a fan of Star Wars shooter games and think Battlefront is a little too bland and unvaried in terms of gameplay, check out the total conversion mod Movie Battles 2. It will transform the game into a funky mix of Counter-Strike and Team Fortress 2 with almost every single possible Star Wars character and location you can think of. For more information visit moviebattles.org ! Do note this is a shameless self-plug as I am one of the developers of the mod.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												The graphics don't hold up compared to something like The Force Unleashed, but this game is still enjoyable to play. The ability to pick and choose certain missions gives you a little extra leeway in how you play the game, and what items you go into certain missions with. It even has two distinct endings, which is close to how many Mass Effect 3 had when it first came out. All joking aside, both endings do make sense in the context of the game and feel satisfying. The lightsaber combat can be a little BS sometimes, especially on higher difficulties, but whenever you have a good, long fight without randomly insta-dying, it's really satisfying and makes you feel like a Jedi.7/10.

												Howdy, folks! So, JKA.. This game is absolutely amazing. As you can tell by my recorded hours on Steam alone (add about another 1400 or so), I've played this game for a little bit. The lightsaber combat is, hands down, only matched (maybe slightly bested) by its predecessor Jedi Outcast. The gunplay, is okay, but come on, this game is called JEDI ACADEMY for a reason! The Force powers add a ridiculous angle to the gameplay in both Single and Multiplayer to keep things from getting too stale. The community for JKA is one of the most resilient communities I have encountered, they have stuck by this game for the 10+ years that this game has been around, and doesn't show too many signs of fizzling out. If you happen to be a fan of Star Wars, I would recommend buying this game, as well as Jedi Outcast, and playing the hell out of them!

												Luke, did I ever tell you about the time I watched a security hologram of my former apprentice, your father, murdering younglings? I tried to tell your mother, who was formerly the democratically elected queen of an entire planet at the age of 15, that I saw it happen, but she didn't believe me despite us having been good friends for nearly five years up to that point. So she took her personal diplomatic starship to a known Separatist world to find out the truth from him, even though she had no way of knowing that he would be on that planet, and even if she did she couldn't have known where on the planet he was, and even if she did she probably should have guessed the reason that he was there in the first place alone would be to either collaborate with Separatist leaders or kill them in cold blood. Luckily, I stowed away by hiding in a space closet, and, when things seemed most hopeful for the galaxy's future when your father decided to destroy the Emperor out of love for his wife, I heroically decided to stand on the landing platform of the ship like a total badass so that he could choke her and endanger the lives of her unborn children. Oh! I almost forgot, you were there too. Anyway, I ended up having to cut off your father's remaining three organic limbs and leave him to die by immolation, even though I thought he was a swell guy up to that point and could have killed him myself to spare him the agony. Oh, and I also looted his lightsaber so that I could keep it for myself in my hermit den, but not before attending your birth, which was overseen by a large white floating robot that said "Ooba" over and over again and, despite letting your mother die even though nothing was medically wrong with her, didn't lose her space medical practitioner's license after that. She was not a good friend.

content:
Posted: March 20
 Star Wars: Jedi Knight- Jedi Academy is pretty cool, I guess. You play as Jaden Korr, an initiate into the Jedi order and the super cool kid in his class because he already has his lightsaber. After the ship you're a passenger on crashes and you fight your way to the academy, you and some loser called Rosh are assigned as students to Kyle Katan, the protagonist from all the other games. From there you embark on an adventure to figure out who was behind the attack on the academy and just how many people you can sword fight at once.It's two, I can barely manage two. I'm not very good. As stated before, you no longer play as Beard Man, but instead as Jaden, a character who's race, gender, and appearance you pick yourself. The options for character creation are limited, but it doesn't really matter outside of appearance since your name, voice, and back story are ultimately the same. Unlike the previous game, Jedi Academy lets you pick your mission and load out before you embark. It's a little bit jarring compared to the previous game where the game flowed from planet to planet and mission to mission through the narrative. The levels are also a lot simpler this time around, with less opportunities to get lost. After each mission you get a single point to put into a force power of your choosing.There are both light and dark side powers to choose from, but the only difference there seems to be between picking Light or Dark outside of the obvious is what Luke says to you after you do enough missions to advance the story. The change isn't unwelcome but I did prefer the more linear story telling in Jedi Outcast compared to the broken up missions in Jedi academy. The gameplay is mostly the same, with a few changes that are mostly just cosmetic. Blaster bolts leave a noticeable black mark on Storm Trooper armor and your lightsaber leaves streaks of burn marks that no amount of Polysporin will fix. You still have the same weapons from the last game with a few new additions. In blasters you get what is essentially a rail gun that kills most enemies in one hit if you can hit them, but lets get to the meaty bits, the space swords.From Dark Forces II onward, Kyle used a single lightsaber, but since you are playing a customization character this time, you have more options. Jedi Academy came out in 2003 when the prequels were still coming out. So because of that, they gave you a few toys to play with. You can still use the normal singular space sword, but you can also use that double headed staff space sword, just like that goofy looking Satan guy from Episode 1  actually 4 . Other than those two, you can also just grab a second space sword and be like that weird kid from that Kingdom Hearts YouTube video.You know the one. Each lightsaber style has it's own moves and special abilities. The single lightsaber can change between three styles, the dual lightsabers are fast and you can use one at a time, and the staff can...Kick...I think, I'm not sure I only used it a few times. Like the last game I checked out the multiplayer, and not so surprising there's a rather large population this time around. Like Jedi Outcast, the dueling community took precedence over the other game modes, and is very much alive. I sat around and hung out for a bit with a bunch of them while they fought one another or ganked someone that was trying to break up duels. While I was hanging out someone in the fat Reelo skin sneaking up behind me and wiggling his lightsaber in my butt. We had fun. But should you play Jeddy Hogwarts?  Yes but only if you can name the blue elephant that played the piano in Jabba's palace in Return of the Jedi. In my opinion, Jedi Outcast had the stronger single player experience, it was a bit longer and better thought out. The last two levels of Jedi Academy were almost exhausting by just how long they were and how many Reborn you had to fight at once. Even then I had a few more hours in the Single player for Jedi Outcast than I did Jedi Academy. But if you're looking for lasting value, the multiplayer in Jedi Academy is still going strong, so you can probably find people to play with throughout the day. I'd still say get both, you can get them really cheap during most sales. Jedi Academy gets 8 Prequel references out of 10. Star Wars was originally supposed to be only one movie.The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												For those of you that hate reading, there's a condensed version of my rambling at the bottom of the paragraph.  Thought I'd write a review for this game but, the hours I have invested in it speak for me in all honesty.  This game is the epitome of my STAR WARS wet dreams.  Custom Jedi, Lightsabers, The Force, and Stormtrooper dismemberment; what more could you ask for?  The story campaign is really good and provides a good time for everyone.  Luke Skywalker is voiced by Mark Hamill and John Williams' original STAR WARS score plays throughout the entire game.  The fanservice levels in this game are just literally off the charts!  However, where this game really shines, in my opinion, is the mods.  This game becomes ten times better once you start sinking mods into it.  The moding for this game is super easy and definitely add to the experience once you've done all you can with the vanilla game.  The mod that gave me over 400 hours by itself was the MOVIE BATTLES II multiplayer conversion mod.  I personally believe the MOVIE BATTLES II mod is the best possible mod to get for this game as it is regularly updated and transforms the battle mechanics of the game completely to make it feel like a more realistic STAR WARS experience.  And that is just one of the thousands of mods for this game floating around the internet.So in short, game by itself is great.  The Story is ok and the STAR WARS fanservice is seemingly endless.  Game with mods is fantastic, tons of mods that add the experience in many different ways.  Highly recommend this game for any person who has ever wanted to swing a lightsaber.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
THE PLOTSTAR WARS™ Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy allows the player to control a character named Jaden Korr, a student who is brought to the academy from Coruscant, after he/she managed to create his/her own lightsaber without any previous Jedi training or experience.Jaden is customizable by the player, with options like different races, different genders, different lightsabers and more.The game takes place after the events of Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast.At the start of the game, the Jedi Academy is attacked by Imperial Remnant forces, as well as by unknown Sith.They manage to steal some information that is critical to the Jedi Academy and the Jedi Order.Jaden then gets dispatched after completing the training at the Academy, and he/she is tasked with keeping the peace across the galaxy.Along Jaden's journey, he/she meets a variety of legendary Star Wars characters like Luke Skywalker and Chewbacca, as well as the iconic Jedi Master Kyle Katarn.Jaden also meets new enemies like Tavion and her Disciples of Ragnos.Besides this, Jaden visits various iconic places like Yavin IV, Tatooine, Hoth & many more.THE GAMEPLAYThe game features a RPG-like system which allows the player to distribute certain points on certain force abilities (the previous instalment, Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast, did not feature this feature).Besides this, the game also allows the player to partially customize their characters, with options to choose things like the race and the clothes, as well as the lightsaber style and colour.The game feels very similar to Jedi Outcast, with many of the controls as well as the hud elements being identical.The combat is very similar to the previous instalments in the series, but the lightsaber combat in particular feels much better than  the previous game. I found the lightsaber to be a much more viable option than the blasters, which were the way to go in Jedi Outcast. In the end, I managed to finish the entire game with only the lightsaber.For the first time ever in the Jedi Knight series, the game allows the player to choose from a number of different missions, which will lead the player to different planets and it ultimately allows them to meet different legendary characters.Before you start any mission, you get to choose what force abilities, weapons and utilitarian items you want to bring, which is a very neat feature in my opinion.The game features some very unique and dynamic levels that can be very overwhelming at times, but they are ultimately a joy to play through.Halfway through the game, you get to make a choice between the light and the dark side, with either option giving you a different path to follow for the rest of the game.The only issue that I have with this game is its length.I managed to finish the game in less than 8 hours, while I managed to finish Jedi Outcast in 12 hours.Nonetheless, I felt like the story and the gameplay made up for this issue, and because you get a choice between the light and the dark side halfway through the campaign, the game is highly replayable.THE TECHNICAL ASPECTSThis game did not have any issues on my end, with no crashes, freezes or any major lag spikes.The game felt very optimized in my opinion.The only reasonable issue that one could have is the lack of modern resolutions for the game, meaning that the game is only playable with black bars if you play on a monitor with a 16:9 aspect ratio.Anyone that has played any of the previous instalments in the Jedi Knight series should not have any issues with this, newer players however might need to adjust to this.The game once again features the brilliant quick save and quick load system from Jedi Outcast, allowing you to quickly save and load at any moment during the game (except the cutscenes, obviously).Lastly, the controls are once again completely customizable, with the ability to rebind every single function at will. MY VERDICT All in all, Jedi Academy is a worthy ending to the Jedi Knight series.Its core gameplay feels very similar to previous instalments, but its story is completely fresh and memorable.If you have played any of the previous Jedi Knight games, or even if you are a fan of older games with some great gameplay and a good story, then you should definitely add this game to your collection.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												One of the games that introduced me to online multiplayer- STAR WARS Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is by far a well polished gem, holding up even today. The game allows you to create your own character, even your own lightsaber, straight from scratch, bringing you on a decently well-paced action-filled singleplayer that has an interesting take on the post-Empire Star Wars universe. Starting off: You are a Padawan named Jaden Korr, sent to a Jedi Training ground deep on the moon of Yavin 4, you meet a fellow Jedi-in-training Rosh Penin, and for some reason immediately become friends, despite Rosh clearly having some form of mental issue. Your ship is attacked, and you are sent careening towards the surface below, and forced to make your way towards the temple that is not too far off in the distance. There, you find the sith draining the Dark Side aura that remained on the temple ground for years with some sort of staff, and thus, you are thrust directly into the story's narrative. The way this game's levels work is fantastic- offering you a chance to pick your own mission and force abilities at the beginning of said mission. Want to be a sith? A Jedi? A well balanced Jedi with all the abilities evened out? You can do that. This game offers many of opportunities to change your playstyle and try new things. If a level isn't working out, you can always leave, and return later once you've picked up a new force power you like. The physics in this game don't support ragdoll physics by any means; but certain force powers let you pick up and swing enemies into walls like it does, and it's great. The multiplayer for me is where this game really shines: A skill based Lightsaber and Blaster dueling arena filled with mayhem and carnage, truly showing who is the best fighter at the end of the day. Sadly, one of the servers that got me into the realm of online gaming, the Purple Clan, is no longer around. But the game's community still lives on strong. This and Republic Commando are one of THE best, if not THE best Star Wars games ever. It even has the best (in my opinion at least) lightsaber physics of any game, scraping and sizzling through walls and insta-killing your enemies with a single swing. The only negative thing I can say, however, is that the Vehicle physics (like the Swoop/Speederbikes) are garbage. They bounce all over the place. Get this game if you can, it's definitely worth the money.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												Jedi Academy is one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made, and possibly even one of the greatest Science Fiction games as well. It will always be a timeless classic, and although aged, its combat mechanics still hold the title of one of the most original, functional, intense, and absolutely fun engines for combat I've ever had the pleasure to experience. The lightsaber combat is at its best, tactical and precise, and at your worst, clicking furiously as Jaden slashes the saber frantically praying to avoid death, which is to say, still incredibly fun. The experience is concise and highly enjoyable, and the voice acting wonderful. The story is nothing new, but there are terrific moments, and never once does it feel unplayable, if only a bit redundant at times (which is quickly forgotten about once you get slashing and deflecting). The only major flaw with the game is a few puzzles that are unfair and require luck or prior knowledge, so keep a walkthrough open. But I assure you, to any Star Wars fan, to any Science Fiction fan, to any video game fan, there's something in here for you that's worth your time and money. I will always love this game and relish the hours of play and replay it has brought and will bring me, and I invite you to do so as well.

content:
Posted: January 15
												Buckle up, as I'm about to tell you a tale of one of the greatest games of all time: Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy is among the first games I ever played all the way back on my first PC when it came out. I remember dad coming home with the case and although some may call this game flawed story-wise and in its mission structure not exactly holding up all these years later, I fondly remember my first hour almost as if it was yesterday. The graphics were a huge step-up from the games I had played until then and I was amazed at witnessing that Star Wars intro I had grown to love so fondly in a game I had heard nothing about but praise from my friends. Immediately after the first cutscene, I was thrown in with a lightsaber in hand and it felt great! I couldn't wait to cut through some stormtroopers, even though I had no idea what the story was about, but that's what it was like back then. Not understanding English back in those days, I was all about the action. And boy, what a game to make you feel like a true jedi this turned out to be. Now that I'm older and have replayed it for about the 20th time (with a new pack of mods, but we'll get into that later), I can appreciate the complexity of the lightsaber combat even more than when I was a kid. Force management, and multiple ways to replay the game with an assortment of different force powers each time. Not to changing into two lightsabers or a dual lightsaber in the 3rd arc of the game, or keeping your trusty single saber from the start, now fully capable to handle any situation with all the saber styles at your disposal. That's what made this game feel like a joy to play, from start to finish, every single time I've replayed it so far (except for the mission where you collect parts for your ship which is a drag). Let's get into the meat, that is the lightsaber combat. Like I said, Jedi Academy was my first Star Wars game on the PC and although I played Outcast and Dark Forces 1/2 later, I never managed to appreciate them as much as this one when I was younger. Now I see Outcast for the amazing cinematic story it provides with the right twists and a progression system that forces you to adapt to the situation, which I honestly prefer over Academy's skill points between missions. Though one thing Academy's got over Outcast where it counts is its last arc where it's all about fast duels with a multitude of bad guys and their cultist supporters with annoyingly strong force powers. Outcast never had that. Its level design and story may have been better, but Academy's combat shines in comparison. This is how you refine a system you developed in your last iteration and make it the spotlight of your game. Everything post-Vjun in this game is pure action and I love it every time I get to that part. The missions up to it feel like a kid's play when you actually think about it, but that's just how great the pacing is too. It doesn't make you feel to powerful right off the beginning, yet by the end, you don't feel overwhelmingly powerful either. Also, the music... John Williams' tracks from the movies. Could've used a few original pieces of work but, not complaining as this is what defines classic Star Wars.The game has aged pretty well and is well-worth your $10 of investment for the ~6-7 hours of entertainment it should provide in a single run. However, let's address the elephant in the room. Yes, Disney now own Star Wars, and hence LucasArts is no more. That however benefited these older titles. Both Jedi Outcast and Academy have their source codes released to the public for personal use, which has given us some of the most amazing modifications that a game can have, keeping it still alive in the modding community to this day. I'm talking about the Serenity Engine, the Evolution of Combat. Among the most advanced mods for this game, bringing in a whole new feel to the long-time classic, in the form of manual parrying, new combat styles and animations, as well as reworked and rebalanced combat system. If you're not into trying new stuff, you may like some of the many mods at disposal all around the internet. I'd suggest into looking through moddb and most importantly http://jkhub.org (the definitive JK mods site since the filefront shutdown) to find some long-time favorites and fan-made side stories, or just expand your game with a few brand new models, animations or sabers. Some of my personal recommendations are Vengeance of the Sith (a really well-made mod that follows Mara Jade through the Jedi Knight universe with great pacing, difficulty and constant action in your face, and this came out in 2004!), Jedi Outcast Academy (JOA is a mod that ports the entire Jedi Outcast story into Academy's newer engine and allows you to switch between the two games on the fly. Really great if you have Outcast in your library and would rather play it with slightly better visuals and the new moves that JA brought to the formula. Though you need to OWN Jedi Outcast), the aforementioned Evolution of Combat (which is also getting a new version pretty soon), Movie Battles 2 and Movie Duels are Multiplayer and Singleplayer modifications, one of which is heavily-focused on teamwork and coordination, and is likely the most active among the Online community, and the other allows you to replay your favorite battles from the movies, and too many other mods to list.Bottom point is, after playing through all of the games through my life, multiple times in fact, I can say for sure that this was a heck of a way to end the series! Amazing combat, great pacing, lovely modding community and an online component that's still active to this day. Don't trust the hours I have on Steam. This is a game that I keep coming back to on a yearly basis to replay or mess around in for a few days, which eventually grows into weeks, months, and wouldn't you know it, I haven't had this gem off my HDD ever since I installed my OS back in 2013. Truly a masterpiece, worth your $10. If you're into this sort of games and would like a more story-driven experience, get Outcast. And if you're feeling like you wanna try them both, go for it! The BEST Star Wars games on PC, along Republic Commando and Battlefront 2.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
An excellent multiplayer game with a forgettable singleplayer campaignI'll go more in-depth with the campaign below, but I'll summarize my overall impression of the game first. Buy it for the multiplayer. The campaign provides a short but fun couple of hours, though you probably won't remember it in a year. The multiplayer, however, provides a much more memorable experience. The dedicated, albeit small, playerbase is testament to that. Okay, so the singleplayer. In terms of customization, Academy succeeds. You get to pick your species/gender/lightsaber from the start. Also, aside from the main narrative driving levels, you're free to pick or ignore missions at your leisure. Unfortunately, no amount of visual flair breathes life into the main cast. Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker make their returns, but only sporadically. Instead, you plays as one of many new students at the Jedi Academy on Yavin 4. As interesting as that sounds, there just isn't a real spark to this game. The story plays out as another macguffin hunt and foiled attempt at resurrecting an ancient evil. The dialog is about as strong as the prequel trilogy's, in terms of tropes. I could critique the narrative structure forever, but you get the point. So ignore it, and just have fun wielding a lightsaber and throwing force powers around. The spontaneous, awesome moments of fighting squads of stormtroopers, or groups of sith-wannabe's make up for any faults.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
Star wars - Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy			* 8/10The final chapter for the Jedi Knight Saga.Kyle Katarn is at last a Jedi Master at the Jedi Academy, thus we will impersonate his new apprentice Jaden, followed by his "punk" friend Rosh. Troubles will start at the very beginning when a bunch of sith will infiltrate the Academy to provide diversion while others drain Some force residuals from the temple and steal Skywalkers log records. A new Sith cult is rising and troubles spread over the galaxy so now it's time for the new Students to go around and solve them.With this new setting we are bound to customize our character's gender, race and appearance. Our lightsaber's hilt and color can be customized as well.The game genere is still a third person action while wielding lightsabers, and FPS when using firearms, but this time we have Lightsaber and force powers since the very beginning,and (after an intro and a training section) we're not playing through an ordered number of levels but we're given a set of 5 levels and we can choose which mission to accept. We're not bounded to accept all of them, as 4 will be enough, but considering for each mission we can improve one light or dark force power at choice it could be wise to complete all of them. After that we will proceed with with story related cutscenes and levels and after that we will be given another set of 5 missions again, rinse and repeat.Even though the story is nicely represented with some more coreographic cutscenes and situations it doesn't really impress and involve the way it happened with Dark Forces II or Jedi Knight 2. A good point is the choice for dark or light path, so once again we can choose which side of the force to join with one particular decision towards the end. As usual the most interesting ending is the dark side, but I'm not here to spoil anymore than this.The engine is once again the same from Jedi Knight 2, but this time the idTech has been polished and improved further with effects, shaders, reflections and saber burn marks on enemies as well. Level design didn't give me the impression of being constant, as I've witnessed marvelous and amazing sections well designed with lot of care and attention for details and decorations, while other areas or levels are more flat or... standard.Gameplay is the real core of this chapter as it has really been improved under many aspects. We have new set of moves such as rolling out or jump when grounded, bounce out when pushed or jumping onto walls, special attacks specific for saber combat styles and in the latest sections of the game we can wield the saber staff or two lightsabers. A particular note goes to one particular section, a mission where you must run all the way with a speeder bike. Even though it's a simplistic section I simply loved it and I'm sure EA had that secton in mind while working on Battlefront.The soundtrack is amazing as always. As in Jedi Knight 2 it uses the Classic tunes from John Williams with dynamic tracks, so fast paced tunes will be played while you're in action, while slow movements will be played while exploring and everything wil be smoothly linked with apropriate musical passages. A bunch of new tracks have been added for specific sections.Unfortunately the impression of this title is that of an expansion more than a new chapter. Of course there are lots of gameplay innovations, a whole new story, but still the story doesn't have the impact nor the importance of the previous chapters, the characters don't give great impressions, specially Jaden, the story is quite predictable and the level design even though it has many sections full of details and inspiration has other sections more standard making the game look... Rushed.+++PROs+++ GAMEPLAY. As in Jedi Knight 2 the combat system is very smooth but now it's improved with new moves, actions, stunts and the chance to use two lightsabers and the saber staff. New force powers are available in the game campaign (though they have already been used in the Multiplayer section of Jedi Knight 2). There are also sections with speeder bikes and Tauntauns to ride. SOUNDTRACK. Once again the game features the amazing scores from John William with the dynamic music system that perfectly fits and follows your actions. A fistful of new tracks have been added. FAN SERVICE. In this chapter there's Mark Hamill Voicing again Luke Skywalker, but there are more elements that might please fans: The Rancor, The Ice Wampa Creature with Tauntauns, Flying imperial troopers and Heavy troopers that really remind a lot of the Phase 2 and 3 troopers from the very first Dark Forces, and always from there... Boba Fett himself. VISUAL IMPACT. The game is getting old but it still looks pretty good thanks to a very good level design, familiar places, attention to details and inspired sections...---CONs--- LEVEL DESIGN. ...Unfortunately that kind of inspiration is not constant as there are sections and levels that look more flat, or less inspired. STORY. This chapter's story is quite simple and linear resulting in a predictable plot and situations. Even though it is well represented by good and coreographic cutscenes it doesn't involve as the previous chapters did, maybe also because the main character, Jaden doesn't have the same charisma as Kyle Katarn. AI. As in JK2 You will face enemies that won't recognize you or the mess and killing you made 10 mts away, or enemies that will run back and forth not knowing what to do, or falling down in pits. This is an aspect of the game that IF it had been improved, it wasn't improved that much. 4:3. Unfortunately, due to the age, the game doesn't support 16:9 resolutions natively. Luckily you can just edit the cfg to force your own resolution. Everything is explained in details in the steam community. CLUNKY ANIMATIONS. There are some clunky or too basic animations in the game such as "non-breathing" idle positions or slow running and walking animations that makes the characters look like they're gliding on the ground.

												Plays remarkably smooth for something as old as it is, and has a fun story to follow.  My only complaint is how random the lightsaber fights actually feel.  I could kill someone with a single stroke, or die over the course of three minutes.  I never found the trick to make it consistent, or seemingly skill-focused.For a game with a LOT of weapons to pick from, you'll rarely use anything beyond your Lightsaber, due to just how effective it is at dispatching opponents, and how well it can defend you on the approach.All in all, a great experiece and still a lot of fun all these years later.  Just minor personal gripes.

Posted: September 2, 2016
												Sure the graphics are outdated, but you don't play this game for the graphics, it's all about the story, the setting and letting your imagination run wild.From vehicles in the desert to iconic music and locations, this game has it all.Explore the wonders of the Force as you learn the ways of the Jedi, then abandon it all for the true power: GUNS. That annoying sith warrior keeps killing you? Bomb him to oblivion, Stormtoopers? Shoot them with bigger guns. It works to certain extent, but guns are no match to the higher level sith warriors you face late game. It's just great and so refreshing to have the option to use different weapons. :)Enter Darth Vader's castle in Vjun ad fight your way through.Then feel like a badass when you finally get good with the lightsaber. Combat is amazing and truly evokes the feeling of being a Jedi.It brought up a constant feeling of wonder. Temples, deserts, forests, space stations, frozen wastes. The galaxy is yours to explore as you complete missions on your way to earn the title of Jedi Knight. This is a great game and I enjoyed it very much. I hope that we can see a new entry in this series soon. If you like Star Wars, this is a must. If you're an RPG fan like me, this is grade A right here.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Don't let my time played fool you (currently sitting at 29 hours), because I played for thousands of hours before acquiring it on Steam. This game was very much my life, my source of satisfaction and very much needed escapism, for the most formative years of my life.I nominated Jedi Academy for the "Test of Time" Award because, as of November 2016, there still isn't a game that comes anywhere close to the complexity, depth, spectacle and accessibility of its lightsaber combat. There's a good reason that people spent years learning the intricacies of a single lightsaber loadout, let alone the other two (two sabers, and dual-ended) and the three styles (Fast, Medium, Strong) of each. This game is astonishing because of how fantastic its combat remains.I mean, it's also got everything else going for it - enjoyable, memorable maps; distinct, unique Force powers; a delightfully cheesy campaign with surprising twists and turns; a great rhythm and sense of pacing; thousands upon thousands of mods...To me, this is as good as Star Wars games get when it comes to the action genres. There hasn't been anything like it since then. It's very much a product of its time, with the freeform multiplayer, open singleplayer levels, a vaguely Quake-esque undercurrent tinting the game's combat and flow, and more. But looking beyond the sentimental attachment I have to it, Jedi Academy remains the epitome of third person melee combat, and as such, it fully deserves the "Test of Time" Award.

Posted: November 6, 2014
												Jedi Academy is an instant star wars game classic and is probably one of my favorites. It feels awesome going through the game as a student of Luke Skywalker and Kyle Katarn, who was the guy you played as in a couple of the previous installments. This game SWAMPS its predecessors in terms of game feel, combat, and customability. Getting your own personal lightsaber was really cool, but later in the game you get to change your fighting style (dual wield, double-bladed, etc.) when you become a jedi knight. Combat is really smooth and using your force powers feels nice. The story, as i should mention, is a great experience and has multiple endings which is a nice touch. I also feel as though i would be at fault if i did not mention the wonderous multiplayer which is really balanced, fun to play, and I have never felt that i had been cheated. This game deserves a 9/10 despite its graphics but there is no harm there considering it is a bit of an outdated game.Totally worth the buy! :)

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Don't let this game's lackluster first act fool you: this game can be quite a bit of fun once it gets going, with most missions managing to mix up the formula to avoid too much repetition and provide some memorable scenes. My personal favorite is probably cutting down cultists with a lightsaber during a speeder chase.The saber duels are some of the most stylish you'll ever see in a game, but sadly the enjoyability of them is extremely hampered by how luck-based they can get when you fight an enemy on even footing with you. I had to resort to save-spamming before and after every single encounter (and there are many, many such fights), and going so far as to abuse range limits and pitfalls to win half of them.Other than that, the only real downside to the game is that so much hack-and-slash, especially with the exhaustingly difficult Sith fights, can wear on the patience. And try not to let your customized character fool you: this isn't really an RPG. You choose your force powers and your saber style, but you only make one story choice in the entire game - right before the climax.All told I recommend trying it out. Just get used to saving your progress every two minutes.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Let me get this out of the way, nobody plays this game for the story.That being said, this game is highly entertaining, to the point where instead it's a the best lightsaber sim game to that it's G-Mod: Star Wars edition, yet TBH I think the mechanics here are far more fun and easier to manipulate than in source.Another way to label it in Unreal Tournament: Star Wars edition since it's got the same engine and mechanics. You'll feel like a real arena player again with the shooting mechanicsh ere, both in SP and MP. Of all Star Wars games, this still has the best lightsaber mechanics. Legit, you can keep fighting new sith or jedi, and you won't get bored because there are so many ways your lightsaber works here, and so many moves you can use to kick your enemy's♥♥♥♥♥ Mixed in with some awesome force mechanics, you actually can feel like a God if you put your moves right. Amazingly, the melee fight mechanics here in swordplay are actually better than some other modern games. I'm shocked that nobody has copied the formula from this game that's over 10 years old.I'll delve into the SP elements a bit: The story isn't really anything new, but it's entertaining to play through because the maps are so well designed and paced out, and you get to choose which missions to go on (though you probably will end up doing all of them). There are many enemies all varying in their strengths and weaknesses, and you can choose to either hack them to pieces of blast them from a distance.But here is what people really stay for this game: Cheats and Mods. You can warp between maps and play god at your own will. You can spawn countless NPCs to populate the map and then entertain yourself by killing them or watch them kill each other (I highly recommend spawning a rancor and a wampa. And this game also is pretty popular for roleplaying, as you can walk around with your friends and do whatever. There isn't terribly too much to do in terms of other than killing, but you can race in this game.So yeah, this game is freaking great. I don't know what else to say and my review is all over the place, but that fits with the context of this game.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												"REMEMBER, ABILITIES AREN'T INHERENTLY GOOD OR EVIL... IT'S HOW YOU USE THEM-Jedi Academy is the follow up to Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast. It uses the same assets and--with the exception of two new lightsaber styles--has mostly the same gameplay. The graphics haven't aged well and weren't that great to begin with. The script is poorly written and the acting is terrible. Level design is hit or miss, with many platforming sections that just don't work and one vehicular segment that is god-awful. There's a lot wrong with this game.-But stay with me here.-Jedi Academy, despite it's numerous flaws, is one of the most entertaining Star Wars games in existence. It, along with Jedi Outcast, nail lightsaber combat with a very responsive system where every directional movement cooresponds with a unique saber slash. The force abilities aren't balanced that well, but they work well in the flow of combat.-You will enjoy destroying many stormtroopers, as they are the general cannon fodder of the game. After that, you will enjoy fighting dark jedi who become increasingly more frequent as the game goes on. Play your cards right in the end and you will be fighting four or five at a time in frantic combat.-Along with the saber you can use a variety of weapons, but really they're only useful for certain segments. 99% of the game will be spent chopping people up, and that's okay.-The story isn't all that compelling, though it has a few parts with great ideas. Kyle Katarn is at your side for a large portion of the game, though often you'll feel annoyed that you aren't playing as him. While you get to create your character's appearance and saber style, you have no control over who they are. Jaden, the main character, is essentially a blank slate who has been victim of incredibly lazy writing. It's hard to tell who to blame for the shoddy voice acting, but it seems like the direction of the script really didn't give anyone room to work with. All the story cutscenes use in-game engine graphics and animations, so it leads to very wooden conversations and some hilariously bad acrobatics.-If you can get over the half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥story you'll get to experience some great combat and a unique handful of levels that go across several different planets. Even if you don't like Star Wars, this is something you could probably get into. Anyone with an appreciation for melee combat done right will find something to like here. Even if you don't care for the story, there's always online multiplayer (which I hear is still active) to participate in.FINAL VERDICT-Lots of flaws with this one, but it's a rough gem. Not many Star Wars game are this enjoyable. If you're looking for a good fix for Jedi action, skip buying the new Battlefront and give this one a try. It's a better game--cheaper too. While I'd ultimately say Jedi Outcast is the better one, Jedi Academy undisputably is more accessible and consistently entertaining. Give it a shot.

content:
Posted: February 21
												I've read one or two reviews which are critical of 'Jedi Academy' on the grounds that it is too similar to 'Jedi Outcast' and doesn't really bring anything new to the table. Whilst I do think that's a valid point, it certainly didn't detract from my experience of the game - an experience which I found immensely enjoyable. In 'Jedi Academy' you play Jaden Korr, who is canonically a human male but can be played as several well-known alien races like the Kel Dor (Plo Koon's race) and Rodian (Greedo's). On my playthrough I chose the Kel Dor, which I admit later regretting due to the fact that the voice sounded nothing like a Kel Dor voice. (Perhaps it's unfair to pick holes in a 14-year-old customisation system!) The rather superficial appearance of your character isn't the only thing you can customise, though. As you progress through 'Jedi Academy', you are introduced to different fighting styles, which culminates in the ability to choose your own lightsaber. If you thought this feature was good in 'Knights of the Old Republic', wait until you see what 'Jedi Academy' can offer. Overall, I'd say that whilst this game falls slightly behind 'Jedi Outcast' in one or two areas (e.g. a less memorable villain, a less challenging final level), it's a fantastic way to spend 10-15 hours (per playthrough, that is), and I'm almost certainly going to return to this game at some point in the future.

												This game has the BEST Lightsaber combat you will ever endure in any Star Wars Game yet to date. The story actually takes place after The Galactic Civil War, thus, meaning that their are EU characters starring in this game which may stray some average Star Wars fans away. But other than that, the game offers a plentiful story and some recognizable characters to say the least, and Kyle Katarn, the cocky but wise Jedi whom was the protagonist in Jedi Outcast. I could go on and on about this game, but honestly if you know a bit of the EU enough to tolerate most of the characters in the game, pick it up. If you'd like to have a fresh new experience on a game that features very impressive lightsaber combat even in today's standards, pick it up.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I always found it curious why Jedi Outcast and its sequel, Academy, dropped the Dark Forces moniker. I had figured it was for brevity and clarity, since Jedi Knight III: Jedi Academy - Dark Forces IV, the name I would have chosen since it's a badass mind♥♥♥♥, alas isn't marketable.But I get it now. It's because the original Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II was very much a Dark Forces game, moreso than a Jedi Knight game. This is due to its pretty awful lightsaber implementation versus its pretty awesome gunplay. The original Dark Forces, just to be clear, had no lightsabers. It didn't need them. For the sequel, everybody wanted to use a lightsaber, so LucasArts tried to deliver. Unfortunately, Kyle Katarn couldn't block any incoming shots effectively, and I guess you could say it's because he was still in training and he sucked at being a Jedi. He was better at being a gunslinging mercenary, and thus the original Jedi Knight game made for a better shooter than a lightsaber sim. Hence, Dark Forces II.The Raven Software sequels are both lightsaber-centered, and ironically, they're both ♥♥♥♥♥♥ shooters. Gone are the Dark Forces days where the gun fights had weight and speed. Now, instead of strafing around like madmen, stormtroopers are content to pretty much just stand there as you shoot at them, and fire back at such a constant rate that you could tap your foot to the blaster's beat. As you sink your shots back into their armor, they stand still, unflinching, as if they didn't realize they had lasers burning through them. It's all very smoothly animated, like butter, but it's also really boring.The guns are also wildly ineffective, since as an alternative, you can run through these guys with your lightsaber flashing, cutting each one down with one stroke WHILE managing to block every incoming shot automatically by just having your lightsaber equipped. This game is exceptional at teaching you just how pointless the guns are, which makes it surprising that you still have to choose your weapons at the beginning of each mission.Once the Dark Jedi start appearing, the game gets good, after a very dull first few missions. I was initially amazed at their ability to cut me down so quickly, and I got frustrated, thinking that the combat was just about swinging the lightsaber wildly and getting lucky. While the sabers don't connect in clear offensive/defensive poses very often, there still is a strategy. For one thing, a few defensive force powers are critical to surviving the tougher Dark Jedi, and once you figure out to map them to keyboard keys, the fighting gets a lot easier. (Of course, the game doesn't teach you this.) For another, circle strafing becomes the best tactic, since most of your attacks get blocked when you swing head-on. The resultant visuals look like a sort of randomized dance, lacking choreography but still well executed. And when you get the kill, the camera goes into a slow-motion 360 twirl around your custom-made character as he/she lands the finishing blows, and that never gets old.You can loosely compare the Dark Forces games' visual style to the original Star Wars trilogy - grungy, old, rough around the edges, beautiful. Likewise, you can compare the Jedi Knight II sequels to the Prequel Trilogy - flashy, pretty, colorful, smooth.Since the story, environments, music (the John Williams themes are cut up, out of place, and butchered here), dialogue, etc. are all pretty bad (or at the very least outdated), the game relies on its blend of lightsaber combat and force powers to keep you interested. Those two elements are good enough to merit a playthrough, which is why I recommend the game.7/10Graphics note: The max resolution available is pretty awful, but can be modified with a config edit (check the forums) to use your HD monitor's native setting. I got it running at 1440p, which looks remarkably good, but the game loaded with a blank white screen every 20th time or so, forcing a game restart. Annoying but not game-breaking, and worth it for the picture quality :P

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This review is based on the mod "Movie Battles 2" So i first bought the game after watching Sylvars "How to lightsaber" videos. 


YouTube™ Video: How to Lightsaber - Jedi Academy 

			Views: 589,447		

			Sylvar decides to try his luck with a lightsaber. Went better then expected? Game: Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy Mod: Movie Battles 2 - http://moviebattles.org/ Power Battles FA (a mod for mb2.		

 After watching them i fell in love immediatly. I tried the base JKA game but 99% of the time has been spent on MB2. Some people consider this game as a classic and if you feel like you would play it again if it was fresh and new, MB2 is your solution.The mod is multiplayer only with an extremely high skill level. The saber system has been completely reworked to offer a big learning curve and actual skill based dueling. Shooting also has a big skillcap and it cant be compared to your typical arcade shooter like Battlefront. Teamplay actually matters.MB2 has different game modes which include: open, full authentic and duel mode. In open mode you can play as many different classes varying from mandalorian with a flamethrower to a wookie and of course, jedi/sith.Full authentic offers you the ability to play classic scenes from the movies/games with preset characters with unique skills. It also includes fun maps to mess around with unique characters like Batman and even Pikachu.Duel mode is exactly how it sounds. It offers the ability to practice your sabering skills against other players.Last but not least, the game costs like 3€ while its on sale so its definetly a cheap one to pick up and you can enjoy for thousands of hours.If you decide to try MB2 and dont know where to begin with or need help learning the basics, feel free to add me. I would be more than happy to help.Original review was made around 600 hours in and reworked after 1300 hours 27.3.17 so its definetly not a game that gets boring easily.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												This game is very personal for me.  I bought this game as a part of a collection called the Star Wars Jedi Knight collection, and my God, was this a wise decision.Years and years ago, back in 2003, this came was released and my Dad quickly bought the game...and one year later, I got my hands on a pirated version of the game (back when my Dad was a huge pirate) and I played the hell out of it.  Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is one of my most played games, and one of the only games that I was willing to finish over and over and over again as a child.  I didn't grow up with an SNES, NES, Atari, Comodore 64, or PS2...I grew up with this damn game.  And as soon as I saw this on sale I had to buy this, because this game was my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed childhood.This is one of my favorite games of all-time for its amazing combat, horrible voice acting and great level design.  As I was playing through this game, as was absolutely astounded by how little it has aged...yeah, the graphics are quite dated, but the gameplay sure as hell isn't.  Swinging your lightsabre around feels so damn good, along with slicing people's arms off and running around with a blaster rifle, and is in my opinion, one of the few Star Wars games that have actually accomplished the feel of wielding a lightsabre, without a damn Kinect to immerse you in the lightsabre.And as I mentioned before, the level design is top-notch, fitting the overall feel of each world that you go through and sets the overall tone for the world that you have selected.  The Rancor world makes you ♥♥♥♥ing scared, while the acid rain level gets this feeling of doom and dispair.  The gameplay is something that I have really missed with modern FPSs, andit's a damn shame we can't get another Star Wars game like this now that Lucas Arts is now a publishing company now that Disney owns Lucasfilm.Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is a wonderful nostalgia trip for me, with great level design, satisfying lightsabre combat, great art design and a great final boss...that's why I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Jedi Academy is the currently latest installment in the Jedi Knight series, that previously starred Kyle Katarn yet, but now you instead control a customizable hero/heroine. The game features both lightsaber combat and the use of blasters, and perplexingly enough some kind of illegal bugzapper weapon that disintergrates people. Odd choice for a Jedi, and nobody seems to give a♥♥♥♥♥♥if you use it. Well, guns are in general pretty awful in this game, and you should stick with the lightsaber. It has a nice feeling to it, it's responsive and the lightsaber battles, as much as it seems to just be flinging the saber around until someone dies, feels cinematic and when you cut someone with it, it's satisfying. Especially against multiple bladed combatants. Unfortunately g_saberrealisticcombat and whatever other command it was to make it so that you could dismember with the lightsaber seems gimped at best, completely removed at worst.It's a shame since that was one of the best parts about Jedi Outcast.The story is somewhat unfocused and kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ you mainly just jump from planet to planet and kill stormtroopers, bountyhunter or the occasional wildlife, much to the dismay of the intergalactic PETA. (I'm joking, I sure as hell hope there's no such thing as People for the ethical treatment of Rancors)A bit later into the game you get to choose whether to have a double bladed, dual, or a single lightsaber. "Why the hell  would I pick a single lightsaber? That seems lame"Well I agree, dual lighstabers are badass, but on another level i feel that it's a lot more practical with the single one, especially since you can switch between three styles. Aside from lasers and lightsabers, you get to choose to use force powers, and can throughout the game upgrade them at your leisure. You can choose from the dark side powers as well as lightside, and you can balance them both without getting a penalty for it. Some of the powers are useless and some are broken, such as level three force lightning. It can kill a whole room of stormtroopers pretty much instantly, but it's useless before level 3.Aside from fighting there are some minor tedious puzzles such as getting prisoners around a rancor, however you can kill it to make the process less annoying. All in all it's a rather solid game with good lightsaber combat, but I'd suggest picking up Jedi Outcast 2 as well.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
10/10, Darth Jar Jar recommends this game.If the two KOTORs are praised as one of the best, if not the best games in the Star Wars universe thanks to their well-written and entertaining story, Jedi Academy deserves the same recognition for its perfectly designed combat mechanics. The JKA singleplayer offers  an  intriguing lightsaber combat featuring 5 different techniques, including a staff and dual sabers, and accompanied by both light and dark side force powers. As such, the game will test your combat abilities and put you against stormtroopers, proper Dark Jedies, and other enemies, letting you enjoy all the perks of being a Jedi. Trust me, there is no better feeling than force gripping a defenceless stormtrooper, choking him while he levitates above a botomless abyss, only to release him the second before he dies to watch his body fall into the darkness and oblivion (dark side forces are always so entertaining!).When finally bored with the singleplayer (replayability confirmed, only the story is a bit dull), I recommend installing Movie Battles II, a multiplayer mode for JKA that features a complete lightsaber combat overhaul, focusing on blocking mechanics and different fighting styles from the SW universe. With this mod, the game changes into an incredibly challenging beast, able both to entertain you for hundreds of hours before you finally master it's combat system, and drive you completely nuts by being defeated and humiliated again and again by duelists better than you. What is more, besides waving with a pointy lightstick, you can take on the role of other professions from the Star Wars universe and play in an open mod with objectives as a stormtrooper, bounty hunter, wookie or various types of droids, all with their own special abilities.Playing MBII is sometimes like being in an abusive relationship. It beats the sh*t out of you in such a manner that you feel like having been an*ly r*ped by a particularly large exemplar of a rancor, but somewhere deep inside you know that you want more. And that you seem to enjoy it.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												What can I say about Jedi Academy? It gets everything from the previous games right, and continues to add atmosphere and story to this ever growing universe. Good points -1. Fighting, the fighting is just down right fun, you can just bounce all around your enemies and dodge everyone of their moves and feel like a complete bad♥♥♥♥♥while doing so.2. Exploration, outside of just getting through the objectives, there are puzzles that while some might not find hard, I did get stuck on for a few minutes and they made me look around at the map and see how expansive they make these worlds, while you may not even explore them all. The secret areas from the previous games return, but unless you really need an extra health pack, and or ammo refill, you don't have much motivation for finding these areas.Bad points -1. Story, if you didn't already know, this game has you playing as a student at the Jedi Academy, while you and your friends, fight this sith cult. There really isnt much to say, you fight the baddies. There is nothing new about this story, we have all seen it in other forms before. Overall - I really enjoyed this game, it is action packed and filled with some variety in what you do, but as I said before the story is a bit lacking, other than that, this is a game that has hours of fun packed in it. I know I didn't talk about the Multiplayer, because to speak the truth, I couldn't find anyone who had the game, and since the only other option are bots, I played like one game, and there wasn't much to say about it, you were fighting enemies like in the game, and it was fun and all, but I didn't think I needed to say much about it.

												Feel unsatisfied with the current SW games out there and it's combat? Well you're in for a steal. I bought this game because heck, i wouldn't call my self obsessed with SW, but i'm obsessed with SW. So this had to become an addition to my collection of games. All i can say that will fit in a brief summary is this: -The game features the best combat in any star wars game i've ever played. It's silky smooth, satisfyingly gorgeous to look as you swing in the wall and a thick line of molten stone and steel remains, i feel in control and engaged. it's just extremely well executed. -The story is extremely fun and engaging, not to the point where you feel absorbed by it, but you'll feel compelled to know what happens next after every mission. Just very well executed as well.-If you're able to find a multiplayer server, or a friend to play with, you'll have some of the most memorable light saber fights you'll ever experience. You'll be laughing your♥♥♥♥♥off as your dream of becoming a sith-lord comes true. UNLIMITED POOOOOWAAA.Amazing game. Truly what i would consider i cult classic in the SW franchise of games.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												This game was a swift sequel of one of my all times favourites (Jedi Outcast) and of course it couldn't match its predecesor.  But as it failed in some areas, it excelled in others. The worst thing about the game are first two mission sets. Playing it in 2015 I was wondering why I completed so many playthroughs, if it doesn't have the soul of Jedi Outcast and feels as old, aged slasher. I was reminded of this the second I had to fight a guy wielding two lightsabers. And then came the lightstaffs. And I loved this game again. Graphisc is old, and there's no helping that, but light effects are still quite nice. The storry is poor and cut in replacable pieces, but has two endings. Maybe the problem is that choosing the Dark Side made me feel like a total♥♥♥♥♥♥ and made some combat unberably tough (jedi masters with staffs are overhyped). And even if you like it the storry beggs for a sequel. But the best assest of the game - lightsaber combat - was perfected in this one. Every calssic style was enriched with some moves, and two new were added (dual saber, and lighstaff). What's not to love?

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												Probably the best online gaming experience I ever had. I remember even training with a friend to get better at it. In our server we would call them our masters and you would have to show respect.The mechanics are incredible, there are infinite combinations and techniques to outmatch your opponent. Single player doesn't really matter. It's all about the multiplayer and committing yourself to get better and better at being a jedi. It's like a rpg but you don't get upgrades or increase level, you evolve and learn by yourself, an "academy" in it's truest sense. I even participated in the ESL jka league.Simply amazing even to this day, it's old I know, but the fact that many servers still manage to survive justifies my review. I will not delve into details but I have to say that the main menu song and the tatooine map one will forever be engraved in my heart.If a new jedi academy game emerged, I would make it my job and go to pro leagues or wtv.
