number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												If you are lazy to read the full review scroll down for short version.Star Wars: Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy, oh boy, where do I start? I started playing this game at such a young age, probably 4-5, but the only reason I knew this game is because I played the one that came before this, Jedi Outcast, which is actually the first video game I ever played. Anyways, enough with my backstory and nostalgia, let's get to the actual review. The game was released in 2003 and the graphics are pretty good for it's time, but if you're a modern gamer who only cares about graphics, there are tons of mods. Continueing on, the game is very fun and has an interesting story. You are a person who wants to become a Jedi so they go to the Jedi academy to learn the ways of the force. As you progress through the game your force abilites get stronger and so does your lightsaber skills. There are also certian force abilites that you can choose to unlock and upgrade yourself, theese include force abilites from the light and dark side. The multiplayer is a hell of fun, the lightsaber combat is good/okay, but maybe a few problems here and there. This game also has one of the least toxic communities ever. But if this game doesn't offer you too much, it has lots of mods, the best one being Movie Battles II. The mod revamps the whole game, even better lightsaber combat, new weapons and force abilites, tons of maps, etc, etc. It includes maps from every battle scene from all 7 episodes, where you can play as the characters from the movies, it ranges from whether you are a clonetrooper fighting on Geonosis to dueling Darth Vader as Luke Skywalker. The mod also includes so many more characters, maps and weapons from the expanded universe. The expanded universe is basically everything that isn't included in the movies, so it's basically made up from books, comics, video games, tv shows, etc. The mod also includes some secret fun maps like a map located in a kid's bedroom, where you play as lego characters, or maps from other movies, such as Aliens or 300. In the end, the game is damn worth the money, and it's very addictive, I may not have a lot of play time on this account but I have played the game far too much. Star Wars fan or not, buy this game.Short Version: The game is made in 2003 and it's pretty good for it's time. Has a good story and good engine. It has a ton  of community mods such as Movie Battles II which let's you play as charactes from the 7 Star Wars movies with new weapons, force abilites and maps. The game is worth the price, go ahead and buy it if you want something addictive to play.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Mit "Jedi Academy" fand die altehrwürdige Jedi-Knight Reihe (leider) einen - hoffentlich nur vorläufigen - Abschluss. Dabei ist das Spiel kein offizieller dritter Teil sondern nur ein Ableger der Reihe. Was mit Dark Forces als eine Art "Star Wars Doom" begann, ging mit "Jedi Knight" und der Erweiterung "Mysteries of the Sith" weiter bis hin zu dem ebenfalls grandiosen "jedi Knight II - Jedi Outcast", welches 2002 zum Kinostart von Episode 2 erschien. Letzteres wurde von der Kritik hochgelobt, neben der tollen Grafik und Action war das Spiel auch atmosphärisch ausgezeichnet gelungen. Auch die original Synchronstimmen von Luke Skywalker und Lando Calrissian trugen das Ihre dazu bei. Ein Jahr später legten die Raven Studios dann mit Jedi Academy nach. Storytechnisch und grafisch macht das Spiel im Vergleich zum Vorgänger leider keine großen Fortschritte. Allerdings muss man bedenken, dass es nach wie vor auf der Quake III-Arena Engine von 1999 basiert. Die war eben auch 2002 schon veraltet, leiste abseits der etwas altbackenen Optik aber nach wie vor ausgezeichnete Arbeit. Die Schusswechsel und hohen Jedi-Sprünge gehen absolut intuitiv von der Hand. Da fühlt man sich tatsächlich etwas an Quake III erinnert. Was das Spiel aber von seinem großen Uhrahn abhebt, und gerade auch als Star Wars Spiel einzigartig macht, sind die grandiosen Lichschwertkämpfe. Diese laufen im Gegensatz zu den Schusswechseln standartmäßig in der Third-Person Ansicht ab und wirken - obwohl Teil des aktiven Gameplays - absolut perfekt szeneastisch Inszeniert. In modernen Actionspielen wäre das, was man hier "live" zu sehen bekommt, allenfalls als stupide Quick-Time-Events ins Spiel eingebunden - siehe The Force Unleashed. Lediglich in Spielen von Platinum Games wie Bayonetta oder Vanquish und mit Abstrichen vielleicht in DMC kann man heute noch derart intensive Nahkampf-Aktion aktiv erleben. Und die Lichtschwert Duelle sowie die Machtkräfte sind es, die sich im Vergleich zu "Jedi Outcast" wirklich verbessert haben. So wirkt der Machtblitz jetzt irgendwie wuchtiger, und ist auch grafisch weit schöner anzuschauen. Auch sind neue Kräfte hinzugekommen, wie der Machtentzug und die Rage. Mir scheinen irgendwie auch die Lichtschwertkämpfe noch intuitiver und flüssiger zu laufen - obwohl die in "Jedi Outcast" auch schon die absoluten Höhepunkte bildeten. Die Kämpfe enden in äußerst sehenswerten Finishing Moves, bei denen die Sith auch schon mal das ein oder andere Körperteil verlieren. Seine USK 16-Werung hat das Spiel somit verdient. Außerdem ist es jetzt möglich, sich im Laufe des Spiels ein Doppelschwert anzufertigen oder zwei Lichtschwerter auf einmal zu führen. Dies verändert die Lichtschwertkämpfe spürbar, und erhöht zusammen mit den verscheidenen Spezies, die als Hauptcharaktere zur Wahl stehen, den Wiederspielwert enorm. Außerdem kann man sich im Laufe des Spiels entscheiden, zur dunklen Seite zu wechseln, was aber nur die Story etwas abändert und wenig Auswirkungen auf das Gameplay hat. Die Story sehe ich tatsächlich als den größten Schwachpunkt des Spiels. Sie ist irgendwie sehr Standartmäßig gestrickt: Neuer Sithkult bedroht die neue Republik, neuer Jedi muss sich dem in den Weg stellen. Auch deshalb, weil die Missionen in verschiedenen Reihenfolgen gespielt werden können - was eigentlich eine super Idee ist - kommt kein richtiger Erzählfluss auf. Diese Mängel werden für mich aber durch das absolut geniale Gameplay, tolle Star-Wars Atmosphäre und das tolle Leveldesign mehr als Wettgemacht. Storymäßig macht es natürlich Sinn, mit Dark Forces anzufangen. Leider ist dies im deutschen Steam Store nicht mehr erhältlich, weil es in Deutschland lächerlicherweise auf dem Index ist, und sich keiner die Mühe macht, es von dort zu entfernen. Ein Schicksal, welches sein älterer Bruder Doom lange mit ihm teilte. Daher empfehle ich, mit dem ersten Jedi Knight einzusteigen.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												In my opinion this is the greatest gem among the Star Wars Jedi first person games (Dark Forces, Jedi Outcast, etc.).I just discovered it in a bundle, but it is well worth the normal full price anytime. You will definitely get an awesome experience for your money.The only negative point (if any), is that widescreen resolutions aren't supported so you will either get ugly black bars or distorted images. It's not too bad on my Full HD screen though and the max resolution itself can go even higher than that.EDIT: Because it was so very helpful, I decided to paste the comment I received to this review:Marto 12 Feb @ 6:32pmYou can have widescreen if you edit jaconfig.cfg file, located usually in ...\Steam\steamapps\common\Jedi Academy\GameData\base folderadd following:seta r_customheight "1200"seta r_customwidth "1920"seta r_mode "-1"or whatever resolution you want and you wil have widescreen perspective.

Posted: September 3, 2014
												If you like men dancing around in tights waving flashlights, this the best starwars title out there. STormtroopers ftw!The pros:The combat is just awesome and visually fun to watch even for these days. The story is tolerably enticing. You're able to use a wide selection of iconic starwars weapons like blaster rifles and thermal detonaters. You are also able to use a single saber, dual sabers, and a saber staff (double bladed hilt) and each has pros and cons, making you able to be just as effective with each. You are also able to customize your force powers  giving it slight RPG feel, and you can have access potentially to all the good stuff. Lighting and force grip and force push OH MY!The cons: When fighting multiple sith, you're liable to get stabbed in the back when you're in a saber lock with the other.Mass genocide of storm troopers. Truly sad to watch.9/10 Would force choke a trandoshian again.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												I say this game is reccomened but only to a true Star Wars fan. For the most part the game is fun but there are moments where I wanted to rage quit.Firstly, the enemies. Basic gun enemies (strom troopers etc.) quickly become easy to kill and pose no challenge after a few missions. Enemies with lightsabres are another story, they can use every power you can making them pretty much your equal, what isn't equal is when you have to fight multiple at once. At several points in the game, the game expected me to take on 5 enemy jedi at once (so I ran past them), but the most frustrating thing is when you kill them. Every time you kill an enemy jedi with your lightsabre, the game decides to do a full 360 spin of your player. It looks cool at first but it wears off quickly and if you kill one enemy jedi when another one is about to attack you, you have to dodge by mmoving, but since the camera is doing a 360 spin, moving in the right direction is hard to do.Secondly, the force powers. You get given powers like force push, pull, jump etc. given to you at the start of the game and they level up those skills as you progress through the story. Then there are other force powers that you can choose to level up before each misson (cure, lightning, shield etc.). Each force power has 3 levels, some powers are very overpowered and others are totally useless (just be sure to experiment with every force power). The other problem is that your force is limited by a constantly recharging metre. But this metre charges very slowly and when using some powers, it doesn't charge at all, a lot of my time in the game was hitting an enemy with force lightning, running round until my metre recharged and repeating, I would have prefered the metre recharge quicker to make combat flow better.There's also a lot of little things like enemies insulting you because you ran away to recharge your force or to avoid combat (and it's made even worse since the enemies can shout at you from a really far distance)That said, there are still some fun and fair challenges during the middle part of the game and there are cool tricks you can do    like throwing your lightsabre and juming up walls (a lot of these special abilities take a while to master).People who love Star Wars will like this game more than other people, just be ready for rage (and don't be ashamed to use a walkthrough)Overall an good game 6.5/10

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Following on from Jedi Knights Outcast, comes a game I enjoyed a little more.  I played this game a long time ago, so knew what to expect, but after recently playing Outcast, I prefer this game a little more.The story follows on the story in Outcast, where someone you've fought was left alive, and now she's back.  This time however, you play as a young Jedi in training, working along side, Kyle Katarn.You can choose your species and gender before starting, and as the game progresses, can choose your lightsaber, fighting style and force powers, whereas in Outcast, you were on a set path.  The game also has light and dark endings, which gives it a little more replay value.  The missions are not linear in a sence of following a strict timeline, so you can even mix it up that way.Combat wise, its basically the same as Outcast.  Gun play is fine, although you learn why everyone is such a terrible shot.  Not as many Stormtroopers as Outcast, so see a variety of different species, which makes things different.Lightsaber duels are a little better I found than Outcast.  But that's maybe just down to a different move set you can have over the standard Katarn one; I'm not sure.  Like Outcast, and because I'm terrible, playing on Easy Mode was a mix bag for me.  100 health, and can fight for ages and never deal damage, then die with one swing from the AI.  Othertimes, one swing and a jump from me and they go down.  Not much feedback on dealing damage I found.Levels are SO much simpler to work out than Outcast.  I had a terrible time figuring out where to go, and what to do, with some backtracking required.  Academy though is a lot more condensed, and a lot more linear, which for this type of single player story, is a lot easier to work with.Overall, a good enough game.  Recommend it, and I'm sure you can pick it up with Outcast in a Star Wars bundle.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												To me this is without a doubt the best Star Wars game to date, even more so than Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast.I played this game all the time back when I was a kid, and it's as fun now as it was back then. The combat feels so great, never before have you ever had such awesome lightsaber combat.Whether Singleplayer or Multiplayer, the combat is great. Really, the only thing that might hold some people off are the out-dated graphics. But since I've grown up with games such as Doom, Star Wars: Dark Forces - the graphics do not bother me the slightest.I haven't played this a whole lot via Steam, but I'm confident that I have totalled well above 600 hours.If you do indeed get this game, I would highly recommend that you get the Knights of the Force mod, it adds so much content your very brain will explode.Have you ever wanted to roam around in multiplayer as Jabba the Hutt wielding a double-bladed lightsaber? Well, with this mod - you can. And it's ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Without a doubt the best mod available for SW: Jedi Academy.Pros:+ Absolutely mesmerizing lightsaber combat (Similar to Mount & Blade in some ways+ Ranged combat is pretty satisfying as well+ Lots of different moves and combos+ Plenty of Light Force and Dark Force abilities+ You can use force push to repel projectiels back enemies! Infinitely satisfying!+ You can use force pull to pull an enemy towards you and then stab them!+ Different Lightsaber stances; Fast, Medium and Strong (The latter arguably a bit overpowered in MP)+ Single Lightsaber, Dual-Wielded Lightsabers or Double-Bladed Lightsabers - the choice is yours!+ Mounted combat! Speedbike + Lightsaber = Awesome+ Hours of fun to be had using the Dev Console to spawn and freeze tons of NPCs to create huge battles!+ Pretty lightsaber trail effects and pew pew sounds+ Character customization, from race and gender to lightsaber hilt and colour. Plenty of options!+ Plenty of clever puzzles using force abilities+ Some major story decisions throughout the game+ Dozens of great mods!Cons:- Some will probably find the story to be lame. Personally, I enjoyed it.- You're a Jedi, it's not like you'll have a hard time killing enemies.- Multiplayer is probably dead, last I played, Knights of the Force mod was still alive and well.- A bit iffy to get widescreen support working- Suffers from typical issues as all older games does

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Following on from Jedi Knights Outcast, comes a game I enjoyed a little more.  I played this game a long time ago, so knew what to expect, but after recently playing Outcast, I prefer this game a little more.The story follows on the story in Outcast, where someone you've fought was left alive, and now she's back.  This time however, you play as a young Jedi in training, working along side, Kyle Katarn.You can choose your species and gender before starting, and as the game progresses, can choose your lightsaber, fighting style and force powers, whereas in Outcast, you were on a set path.  The game also has light and dark endings, which gives it a little more replay value.  The missions are not linear in a sence of following a strict timeline, so you can even mix it up that way.Combat wise, its basically the same as Outcast.  Gun play is fine, although you learn why everyone is such a terrible shot.  Not as many Stormtroopers as Outcast, so see a variety of different species, which makes things different.Lightsaber duels are a little better I found than Outcast.  But that's maybe just down to a different move set you can have over the standard Katarn one; I'm not sure.  Like Outcast, and because I'm terrible, playing on Easy Mode was a mix bag for me.  100 health, and can fight for ages and never deal damage, then die with one swing from the AI.  Othertimes, one swing and a jump from me and they go down.  Not much feedback on dealing damage I found.Levels are SO much simpler to work out than Outcast.  I had a terrible time figuring out where to go, and what to do, with some backtracking required.  Academy though is a lot more condensed, and a lot more linear, which for this type of single player story, is a lot easier to work with.Overall, a good enough game.  Recommend it, and I'm sure you can pick it up with Outcast in a Star Wars bundle.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												You think of a lot of Star Wars games and you're probably thinking of Republic Commando, Battlefront, Knights of The Old Republic and so on. This is the game that I think everyone, even if you're not a fan of Star Wars, should play it. As mentioned in PCGamer, it makes the lightsabers feel like sabers rather than a neon stick with high damage. These lightsabers are rods of superheated plasma, and my god does it let you know that. Stand close enough to a wall, and where your saber would clip through the wall, it cuts it, leaving a burning trail through the wall. If it rains, the water hisses and makes steam. These babies are also one or two hit kills too - you can chop off your enemies limbs with finesse if you're fast enough. There is absolutely nothing stopping you from never using a gun (apart from one mission where you are captured), and the sabers themselves also have a vareity of unique moves depending on which saber you can choose. Yes, you can customise your saber. Colour, hilt and type. Want Darth Maul's red saber staff? You can choose red as your colour in MP (or if you want, pick an aggressive shade of orange. The purple is also known for striking fear into the hearts of your enemies). You can also customise your character. In fact, the only solid thing is your name, the helpfully ambigous Jaden Korr. Your race, gender and clothing is up to you. Also the female player is voiced buy Jennifer Hale, otherwise known as female Shepard.The multiplayer community is also somewhat active, but remember, if you're a beginner to the saber (even if you've finished the game) there is always that one guy who is just better than you. It can be aggravating, but get some friends, and it's amazing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Ever wanted to summon a hundred sith and 20 Luke Skywalkers to see how they fare against each other? You can do it in this game! (with cheats though). Also, this game has a rather interesting single player story mode I played through multiple times and sank approximately 40 hours into. Click here for an Under 5 Min Review of this game!Pros:1. You can be a Jedi! Also, it has Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker in it!2. A plethora of mods!3. Although the story is linear, the levels offer a variety of experiences (crashlanding on a planet and repairing your ship, while trying to escape a sand worm; fighting Boba Fett; disarming a bomb-rigged train; speeder chase, and many other routine adventures a Jedi Padawan/Knight goes through)4. Awesome acrobatics, swordsplay and Force powers, which feel way more fluid and natural to the game than the guns.5. Great sandboxing potential of both SP and MP. You think this plain on Tatooine would make a great battlefield? Spawn in Boba Fett and 3 Kyle Katarns and see who wins, then spawn in 20 Boba Fetts and 60 Kyles. (spoiler: Boba Fett wins every time, since he's immortal). Would you make this roof to roof jump on the moving train if you had a speeder with you? Spawn in a speeder and try it out!6. There is an active multiplayer community and the sandbox is real on the servers (there are banks, quests and other different RPG-ish kinds of stuff). There are some classic FFA, TDM or CTF servers too. While the sandbox is something very interesting and unique to this game, I can't really say it was that big of a deal for me.Cons:1. Dated graphics and cinematics.2. Very predictable and linear story.3. Gunplay is pretty subpar, compared to lightsaber combat and Force powers.4. Possible compatibility problems with Windows 7/8. Also, some tinkering is required before you can set it to 16:9.This is one of the games, that aged really well, considering it's over 10 years old. If older graphics are a problem for you, there are mods partially fixing them, as well as adding a bunch of new things to the game. The most fun I've had with this game was either by spawning in enemies and allies and organising battles royale, or trying to get speeder jumps in original places (for example a roof to roof jump on the moving train level). I return to this game every now and then for the great lightsaberplay and to have some fun cheating in enemies and vehicles.You might encounter compatibility problems, so purchase at your own risk!Verdict: 9/10 - Would get choked by Kyle Katarn again (no homo).

content:
Posted: October 28, 2012
												Not only is this one of the best multiplayers games of all time, it's so timeless that it's still active to this day. It's one of those games with combat that you'll pick up really quickly, but so layered and well made its depth will surprise you. There's something in this game for everyone, and it's highly moddable. This is a must have not only for Star Wars fans, but for anyone who appreciates skill based melee combat with Quake-like FPS drizzled on top. Now if you're a fan of escaping from how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ life is, a lot of RP servers are up. Wanna be a Jedi, Sith, Bounty Hunter or a Smuggler? Hop into a server with a dozen of your fellow virgins and create your own stories. I recommend ::JEDI:: for its remarkable lack of mary sue anime characters.

												At first I thought this game was kinda lame, but as i learned more about the combat and unlocked more force power and weapons I changed my mind. I easily see why so many people like this game, including myself. The saber combat is much more engaging than something like the force unleashed. However, you kill sooooo many people in this game, I feel more like a sith lord than a Jedi.

content:
Posted: January 28
												This game is a technical mess, a narrative disaster, that also still manages to be kinda fun. Weird, right?The game barely works. It's as if every mechanic in the game was loosely coded and then given 0 polish. You character moves with little precision, and the lightsaber is almost complete blind hack n' slash. The gunplay is... ok I guess. The blasters all feel like blasters and have neat dual firing modes. The enemies are consistently inconsistent, often times being completely ineffective, glitchy, and then switching on the fly to Dead-eye♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and killing you very quickly. I was fortunate to not have any hardware issues, and had a good FPS.The story is pretty terrible. What's there is mostly just mountains of OT references, and what isn't is usually painfully awkward dialogue, or just dumb writing. Is this what people think Star Wars is?That said, it's hard to find another game that lets you bounce around, zippin' and slashin' like a Jedi and sh*t. If that's all you wanted, I recommend this game. If you were looking for some depth or something.... more? Then I do no recommend this game. I'm still gonna play it once and a while whenever the ol' internet's down... so there's that I guess.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												This is simply one of those classic Star Wars games that defines a generation... I can personally say that this game features one of the most diverse and enjoyable leveling experience that I have ever had the privilege to enjoy. Not only does it feature complex puzzle and mechanics, but it has incredible combat as it is powered by the Quake 3 engine. Not only does this make for a boredom-free leveling experience, but it is also allows for some of the most challenging and entertaining PvP. While the combat is superior to it's predecessor due to brand new combos, force abilities, and the addition of Jar'Kai duel wielding and double-bladed saber staffs, the story is very much lacking as it is cluttered with plot holes and meaningless absurd plot devices. Fortunately, the positives of this game easily out-weigh the awful story. As a whole this game is an incredible feat, let alone for something made over a decade ago and is certainly worth the minimal fee of $10. In addition to this game I'd like to recommend a few other classic Star Wars titles including: Knights of the Old Republic, KotOR: the Sith Lords, Battlefront 2, and the rest of the Dark Forces series if you are into older games. I also recommend a mod called "Jedi Outcast - Academy mod" Which can be found on moddb.com and allows you to play the full Jedi Outcast campaign on the updated Jedi Academy engine. With that I leave you, and remember the Dark Side has cookies and force lightning is over-powered. >:D

content:
Posted: March 28
												I feel conflicted about this game.Pros--Character custamization. (Oh, its really cool, from your face to your clothes to your lightsaber! Might not be as indepth as our modern standerd but still cool.)-First person shooter and Hack'n'slash. (Neat combo.)-Quite a few missions.-Star Wars!!!And oddly enough thats where it ends. Cons--The lightsaber duels feel like they're *click click* and hope you hit your target. (edit) to me, combat feels rather simplistic, but, they do have some skill involved according to review comments.-The difficulty get artifically inflated as you play, with more enemies carrying sabers and using force powers, so you eventually have to save after each fight just so you don't get stuck playing the samething over and over again. -Saber duels are more based on luck rather then any skill, maybe you hit them, maybe you don't, maybe thay hit you and kill you. -Force powers are a drag, offensive ones don't work most of the time, but you can't defend yourself from them like your enemy can. You have to spend a force power upgrade point every mission, so once you get the once you want and need, you don't want the others and they just get in the way when selecting powers. Force powers are seperated into light and dark side powers and by your choices you can warrent at most comment on your choice. I hate this because it's said early in the game that "Force powers themselves aren't good or evil, but it's the user." So why the #*%4 can't I use force lightning without being judged.-Blasters become useless in the later game as force users and Boba Fett(why?) just side step your shots, litteraly.-Missions don't really flow with the story, which isn't one of the better ones at that.Personal thoughs-This game feels more like a "what could have been" tittle. It makes you want a good Star Wars RPG like Knights of the Old Republic mixed with some of the combat stylings of this game. It's a game that starts out good, then it leaves an after taste, and finally you just end up feeling bad. Sort of like cheap booze.Do I regret buying the game, no, but it is a game that could be done better. the worst part about it is that you end up wanting something better, and you look at the game wanting to improve it.Side note-"only siths deal in absolutes." Steams rating system is "yes" or "no". Think about that for a second.My review is based on personal feelings and experiance. I would rate this game 7/10, though to me this game doesn't feel as good as others make it out to be. Again, thats my oppinion.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												I do not regret playing this game, I simply believe there are other games that may be more worthy of paying 10+ hours of your life to experience.Depth: 5/10Story: 7/10Replayability: 6/10Controls: 4/10Value: 9/10 (Paid $2.50 for it, got over 10 hours out of it)Momentum: 5/10Memorability: 3/10 Time Debt: 3.5/10Overall: 5/10*By "Momentum" I mean, the extent to which I wanted to keep playing the game at any instance during gameplay. For example: "Quake" for the xbox 360 was one of the most painful games I've ever played, and I only continued the game because I was an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥.  It would get a 1/10.*By "Memorability" I mean the extent to which my life was made richer by experiencing this game, i.e., was this a game that I'll be thinking about and talking about with friends years down the road?*By "Time Debt" I mean the extent to which I believe this game was worth the time it took to beat the game, i.e., in hindsight would I agree that there were no other things I would've rather spent my 10+ hours on? Notable Mentions:-Occasionally there are areas/levels which have repetative audio segments, which can get really annoying. (Looking at you Blenjeel merchant rescue!!!)-There seems to be an instant jump in difficulty midway through the game.  Not necessarily a bad thing, just different from the usual.-Force Lightning.  Always a good decision, regardless of star wars game. Hah-I went through the game using mostly a lightsaber.  On normal difficulty, lightsaber combat was really just kind of hack & slash with little thought needed.  On normal, it's very much so a scratch-ur-balls-while-playing kind of game.All these ratings are based on 2016 expectations.  For its time I believe this game could've easily been an 8/10 or higher.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This game is a classic, one of the best Star Wars games ever made.You play as Jaden Korr starting off as a Jedi Padawan and as you play through the game you become a Jedi Knight or Master, the game is based along the same storyline as the Dark Forces games and like the Dark Forces games it's based after the Galactic Civil War between the Rebelion and the Galactic (Sith) Empire of course if you've seen the movies you'll know the Rebels win and they form The New Republic, because of how few Jedi are left and there are even less Jedi Masters some students were asigned more than one master, Jaden and another Jedi Padawan Rosh Penin under the jedi master Kyle Katarn.The story says you are a Human Male but you can chose to be a Kel Dor male, a Rodian Male, a Female Human, Twi'lek and Zabrak changing your race doesn't change how you sound, you will always have one of two voices, aswell as that you can customize your lightsaber, this game has the second best or the best lightsaber customization to Star Wars Galaxies, again the story says Jaden has a purple lightsaber but you can change the colour if you want, but in singleplayer he can't have a red lightsaber, you can also choose from a few handles for each saber, one is the saber Anikan uses and another is the one Obi Wan uses, aswell as a single saber you can use duel sabers and a saber stalf saber stalfs have their own unique handles too, chosing duel sabers or a saber stalf over a single saber does seem cool but the single sabers are more flexible with three attack modes, light medium and heavy each with their strengths and weaknesses.The story of the Dark Forces games is probably one giant "What If" scenario, what if Anakin didn't wipe out all the Jedi in the temple what if he missed a few and they escaped? even though irionically his son Luke, (with the help of his badass buddy Kyle Katarn) trains these people to (most likely) become amazing jedi. Like most to all jedi-themed classic Star Wars games you can chose to be good or bad, i will not explain in this review for spoiler reasons how to chose your side and how it will end.Multiplayer is very much like Quake 3 only with three types of grenades, the ability to use the force and customize your lightsaber and of course you can chose a red blade.Like Quake 3 you can chose from a large nomber of characters from the Dark Forces games even people you don't see in Jedi Academy aswell as your own characters, the character creation is exactly the same as in singleplayer.You can chose to be focused arround dark side powers or light side powers not both, each side has their own unique team power in the team-based games, some powers act differently to how they do in singleplayer and you can have power "loadouts" making it easier to change power builds.There are six game modes, Deathmatch, TDM, Duel, Power Duel, Capture the Flag and a class based Siege gamemode.Deathmatch and TDM are basically the same as always, your cloths and saber is coloured based on what team you are on and in TDM you can chose to have it light powers vs dark powers, the first team to hit the score limit or the team with the most score when the time runs out wins.Duel is also very self explanatory, a good old 1-on-1 battle Power Duel is 2-on-1 but the person by himself gets a few advantiges to even things out, you can chose to have weapons or go lightsaber only, lightsaber only is probably the best choice for duels since there aren't any weapons or powerups inside the arena, the person who hits the win limit or has the most wins... well wins.Capture the flag is what it always has been, if you've played Quake 2, 3, any Untral Torunament or Metal Techs 4 through to 7 (the Tribes games) you'll know what it is, like all team gmaes in Jedi Academy and most team-based games/gamemodes there are two teams.In Siege there is an attacking team and a defending team. The attackers have to make their way through the base and the defenders have to stop this, i havn't played much of siege persenally but i know that it has vehicles and it's class based with no AI, vehicles and mounted guns.Also you don't have to have a lightsaber in Multiplayer for those who want a little bit of an extra chalange, and play agenst players since the AI aren't that smart even on the Jedi Master difficulty.If your Star Wars dream was to become a Jedi i hightly reccomend this game aswell as that it's an awesome game in general, there aren't many Star Wars gems like this anymore since EA owns the rights to the Star Wars games so we must enjoy the few we have left.

number of helpful: 9 of 25 people (36%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Honestly, I didn't expect to enjoy Jedi Academy as much as I did. Like with Jedi Outcast, I simply don't think it lives up to the quality of Dark Forces 1 or 2.This is not to say the game is bad. Jedi Academy is definitely an improvement compared to (Dark Forces 3) Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast for Raven Software, but I can't help but wonder if the game is simply too shallow for me to enjoy.The multiplayer, however, I can see as being enjoyable if I had friends to enjoy that content, so if you want the best Jedi Knight multiplayer community and mod-support, then this is definitely your game.The Star Wars Fan-Fiction SimulatorI say this with all good intentions. Ironically, as I found Outcast's reliance on the lore my main gripe, the reliance on the lore is what makes Jedi Academy entertaining.You choose a template of characters, outfits and lightsabers--for some reason each alien species is set for one gender--and revist locations of the movies. You'll fight alongside heroes like Chewbacca, Kyle Katarn, Luke Skywalker. You'll fight against the snow Yeti's from Hoth, Boba Fett and the Sith Apprentice from Outcast. While I hate how the series has become more fan-service than creating original characters and stories, I can't deny there is something to enjoy in buddying up with your favorite hero. To make up for the lack in creativity, the level design (and variety) are what makes this change bearable.Not only will you have a more colorful variety of locals, but the mission-structures have changed, some for the better and some for the worse. Missions that have you exploring for a secret base while lost in the tundra winds of Hoth or scavenging for pieces of tech while avoding the sands of a worm-infested desert are a nice change of pace.What doesn't work are the racerbike mission, the Rancor "Stealth" mission, and the other side-operations where the gameplay doesn't feel like it was polished enough to be fun. Relying on the allies' AI to act properly is a terrible idea because there's no command system to tell them what to do (like running away while I distract a Rancor), and I think some gameplay changes (the rancerbike jousting mission) have broken controls. Thankfully, the game doesn't require you to play every single level, and you can always back out to choose something else. So instead of a completely polished, excellent campaign we get probably 3/4ths of good ideas, and the rest that are meh at best, which helps to mitigate the tediousness of the lightsaber combat.Supposedly the Best Lightsaber Combat Ever?Maybe I don't understand the lightsaber mechanics, but I fail to see what makes JA's mechanics the best. It's exactly the same basic mechanics from Jedi Knight 1 & 2: Hold LMB to attack, RMB to do a special/light-saber throw. However, they added in combo-based moves to the fighting system that feel as demanding as a fighting game. The best I can say about this new system is that there is a great sense of fluidity in the animations. Jumping off of walls, doing cartwheel attacks, power-strikes or crouch attacks, and evading a down-ward stab by rolling away go to make the combat feel the most lively. Weapon styles and attack strategies are also added to give you more options in combat.All of this, I agree, makes the combat feel so great.The drawback to this combo system is that you have to rely memorizing the moves, and when you are trying to use them it can feel too rigid to get down properly. But maybe that's just a skill-barrier I haven't mastered yet; it's not the reason why I find this combat system shallow.The reason why I'm not engaged in Jedi battles is that I cannot read my enemies' moves or know, for certain, whether I'll land a blow or not. I've had better luck winning battles if I flail around and hold the attack button then try to land precise strikes, either with one-handed light-sabers or with two of them.Maybe the combat is balanced for multiplayer only. Towards the end of the campaign where the game litters you with Dark Jedi, I never felt the combat system was refined enough to make me feel like I earned each victory. I preferred cleaving through the hordes of Stormtroppers, Droids or Smugglers because my Force abilities and my arsenal would be more useful. (Seriously, Jedi can reflect rockets?)Why Is Jedi Academy OK but Not Great, and Why Is Jedi Knight 2: Outcast Bad?For one, the level design and the lightsaber mechanics are much more refined than Outcast ever hoped to be. Another reason, as mentioned before, the game will vary up your playstyle either by fighting new enemies or making new mission  types that change up your arsenal to not make you grow bored of the lightsaber combat.That last part is what Outcast failed to remember when it made lightsabers the most efficent weapon to use to protect yourself and to mow down your enemies. When fighting the giant Dark Stromtroppers with rockets/concusion rifles, it's best to attack them with heavy weaponry from afar than charge in with Protect enabled.Also, by giving you the lightsaber from the get-go, you now have the Force abilities from the start to make up for relying on the light-saber so much in Outcast. The only thing I don't think Raven Software got right is making a better story. It's so obvious what happens from the first few cutscenes that the "suspsense" is laughable. The canon characters were the only bits that felt as interesting as Outcast.Unfortunately, the story is not the only disappointing feature of Jedi Academy. For whatever reason, you won't unlock a second saber style until the first round of missions are done, and then you won't unlock a new lightsaber type until you get to the final 4/5 missions. There is no New Game Plus mode to make replaying the game entertaining, not unless you enable cheats which can break the game if Force points aren't allocated properly.This is such a majorly missed opportunity where the game could've focused more on how the three combat styles (one-handed, two one-handed, two-sided) relied on different tactics when fighting enemies throughout the campaign. (I've heard some argue it was for balance reasons but I don't see why that couldn't be an option.)Even then, I still don't think the quality of Jedi Academy, even at its greatest and ignoring its worse aspects, ever reaches the peak of Dark Forces 1/2. (Something I've gone into great detail in my Jedi Knight 2 Steam review.)The only reason I'm complaining about the assocation of the games is because I have expectations from the previous games that haven't been reached.A Bitter End for a Promising New BeginningDespite everything I've gone through with Outcast and the worst parts of Jedi Academy, I would still like this series to be given another chance.I'd love for Raven Software, or another company, to try the Dark Forces/Jedi Knight format (or even make a Jedi Academy sequel forgoing everything) one more time because I think what they achieved here is a step in the right direction. Something along the lines of Witcher 1's weapon styles, added into Dark Souls/Risen 1/Spectacle-Fighter gameplay, and given the Star Wars treatment would be a beautiful game to play. And because of the longevity of this title by its fans is still strong I think there is more than enough of an audience who would be willing for another game.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
 Short Review: Pros:- Not too bad Graphics- Amazing Storyline- Force Combat!- Backflips- Awesome community- No DLCS!Cons:- Poor Hit Detection- You need to install a multiplayer mod- Jedi Academy Multiplayer is dead- Lightsaber combat can be found difficult- Lack of Servers- Poor Map Design- Some Unbalanced LightSabers (Dual, Double-Sided,Standard)Full Review:STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy™ . Take on the role of a new student eager to learn the ways of the Force from Jedi Master Luke Skywalker. Interact with famous Star Wars characters in many classic Star Wars locations as you face the ultimate choice: fight for good and freedom on the light side or follow the path of power and evil to the dark side. This is a singleplayer or multiplayer based game. The multiplayer is most popular due to the lack of people bothering with the story line. I mostly use Multiplayer so my review will take place in the Multiplayer.  Combat against other players and AI. The Combat system on the most popular mod, MBII ( Movie Battles 2) is amazing. It has everything to offer as well as playing with a real person instead of a coded character. If you are a Padawan and not ready to be a jedi nor a jedi master, I suggest you play on Multiplayer and make a private match, NOT USING MBII but instead Evolution of Combat 3. All the download links to the mod will be at the end of the review. In EOC3, You can launch a .bat file from the downloaded folder in your Steamapps (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Jedi Academy\GameData\GameData\Evolution_of_Combat_III>)and you can choose which one.  Evolution of Combat III:  In this mod, You can spawn any NPC, change maps, change saber and change your class to jedi master as well as playing god. You can spawn in Chewbacca and make him fight Darth Vader. Or you could spawn in Luke Skywalker and make him fight against a sith lord. It's all up to you how you play god. MovieBattles 2 FACT: Did you know that on the majority on servers, they have Fin and Kylo Ren? Including Kylo Ren's Lightsaber! About The Review: I will mark this review as positive and will return in the near future to the mod page to see what other mods they have made. Last time i heard, there will be a Rogue One Mod with EVERYTHING in it at the end of the year. Maybe i might add more to this review. Thank You:


YouTube™ Video: rzr JK:JA Fragmovie 

			Views: 6,305		

			| Presented by Till | ESL Profile: http://www.esl.eu/eu/jkja/player/2395664/

If you like you can add me on steam and we can play games like CS:GO, Minecraft etc. Also dont forget to rate my games and let me know what you think of them!Mods:https://www.moviebattles.org - Movie Battles 2www.moddb.com/mods/evolution-of-combat-iv - EOC IVwww.moddb.com/mods/serenitysabersystems - EOC III

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												(English/Русский ниже)One of my favorite games. However...Don't buy it. Why, you ask?Well, it looks like latest patches completely broke several scripts (trust me on that, I know each corner of this game), which made singleplayer completely unplayable.Just some examples:-on vjun2 you got unskippable glitched scinematics with Kyle (after cable and pumping the water). This bug was brought from XBox, by the way-on rift, vjun3 and several other maps some level parts are destroyed from the begining of the level instead of being at one piece until corresponding script taking action. Giant Rancor level is absolutely flat, with no objects.Well, you may want to buy it for multiplayer, but that's it.P.S. "Thank you", Disney.Скажу сразу - сама игра великолепна и до сих пор остается одной из самых любимых и интересных.Почему отрицательный отзыв ? Почему не покупать?Что ж, ответ один - кривой патч.Если Вы уже играли в эту игру ранее и проходили ее, то увидите, что многие скрипты сломаны (поверьте, сам я знаю эту игру пости наизусть)Например:-Миссия Vjun 2б обязательная сюжетная - после включения насосов в комнате с кабелем  включается ролик:Кайл пытается запрыгнуть в дыру в потолке и... ничего. Ролик повисает, пропустить нельзя, перезагрузкой не лечится. Пришлось шаманить с читами. Кстати, баг этот в ПК-версии изначально отсутствовал и был принесен из XBox-версии.-на миссиях rift,vjun3 и некоторых других объекты, которые должны ломаться только по скрипту, сломаны изначально. Например, на rift - это длиннейший мост, дыру в котором невозможно перепрыгнуть - уровень непроходим без noclip. Уровеньс Гигантским Ранкором так вообще плоский, без единого ящика (кто играл, поймет).Тот случай, когда посоветую все-таки спиратить хорошую игру. Тем более, что Lucas Arts канули в лету.Можно купить разве что для мультиплеераP.S. "Спасибо" Диснею.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Decent. For a Star Wars game, this was probably the best at the time. Fun to whip a lightsaber around but it's lackluster in terms of plot, graphics, and even gameplay. Level design is mosly uninspired.Completing all the missions and the primary campaign will take about 10 hours. That's probably all the time you'll want to play this game. Worth picking up if only to see how the lightsaber combat works.

number of helpful: 4 of 24 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Pros:+ For using a very dated engine, it looks pretty good+ Interesting Story+ Uses the original movie soundtrack+ Decent amount of character customization+ Missions vary in length, so they don't feel like you're doing the same mission again and againCons:- Being able to choose your missions is great on paper, but because only one of the 5 missions you get every section actually affects the story, they feel like a massive waste of time- Ridiculously dumb enemy AI- Force powers seem disappointingly weak- Usage of original movie soundtrack is iffy at best, some times it fits perfectly, other times, not so much- Shooter gameplay is rather bland- While the lightsaber customization is good, most of the bosses can be beaten by either swinging your saber around like a mad man or simply shooting them with the concussion rifle, which can render many of the special moves pointless- Being forced to upgrade powers in order to enter a mission is annoyingTL;DR: Despite getting some things right, it's decent at best. If you've got money to burn, then buy it. Otherwise, your not missing out on much.

number of helpful: 0 of 15 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												PROS:- Great Saber Combat.-Makes you look and feel like a badass. -Great saber creation.CONS:-No resolution for my monitor (widescreen).-Few options for character creation.-More options for saber creation than character creation.-Cringey cutscenes and characters.-Checkpoints are broken. -Multiplayer is DEAD.-Gun play is bad.-Animations are badly done.-Repetitive missions.PREFERENCE:-You can draw with the lightsaber.-Graphics are EXTREMELY outdated (I know it's a 2003 title but still "outdated".)FINAL VERDICT:3/10This game is great, if you're looking for nostalgia. Saber combat is great, I LOVED it - IF you were against another Jedi or Sith. Otherwise it's almost all the time 1 hit kill. Graphics gave me nightmares but I was able to get over that. The real nail in the coffin was how repetitive the missions were. Don't buy this game if you're not a HUGE HUGE Star Wars fan.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												This game is alright. Not bad, but still not good. For starters, the lightsaber is, for all intents and purposes, the only viable weapon. The guns have a hard time hitting anything, and do very little damage when they do. The lighsaber, on the other hand, will kill most humanoid enemies in a single, well-executed swing and can even be thrown to instakill from a distance. It also does a good job of deflecting bullets, which guns leave you completely vulnerable to. While this may not seem so bad, it gets worse. The lightsaber, while still much better than any of the gun, has its own issues. Instead of simply swinging, your Jedi will try to do all sorts of visually impressive lightsaber maneuvers. This equates to flailing around awkwardly and sometimes even completely missing enemies that are right in front of you.Now, for the icing on the cake. The vehicles. Vehicles are terrible in most games. Raven Software apparently took this as a personal challenge. While on a vehicle, you can move forward and backward and turn with the mouse. The problem is that moving your mouse left or right will only move the camera a little bit. In other words, you'll have to drag the mouse several times in the same direction to turn. And of course, like any game with bad vehicles, Jedi Academy has levels where operating them is required. Overall, this game is, like I said, really not THAT bad. Using the lightsaber does provide a decent amount of enjoyment, and it's pretty satisfying to kill people. But I wouldn't pay full price for it, and I'm happy I didn't.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												I was raised on Dark Forces, Dark Forces II (Jedi Knight) and Jedi Outcast. This switch to third person view and the more generic "I am a nameless random Jedi" character you play instead of Kyle Katarn makes the game not very compelling to me. I played about 4-5 hours of it (pre-Steam) back in the old days, got bored with it, and forgot about it.The upside is that it is, of course, much prettier than the older games. 3rd person view means lightsaber dancing looks cooler.But overall, for me it was the most forgetable of all Star Wars games, namely due to my lack of interest in who I was playing (who can be customized up the wazoo, at least for a 90's era game). But Asypr/Lucasart's wish to make the game like an RPG, without the RPG elements, were its downfall. You play and watch Star Wars for the story and for the characters, not (just) the gameplay and the graphics.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												The driving question of all Steam reviews is quite simple, honestly: Do you recommend this game? My answer isn't as simple.The combat is, more often than not, very responsive and fun. It gets very muddled once Force powers are added, to the point that I lost interest in it.Level design is utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ with terrible checkpoints. It also has a vechicle level, with little to no explination as to why it was needed. along with some terrible platforming.Graphics are okay for their time, but haven't aged very well.The multiplayer is the high point of the game, if you can find matches. Very fast paced, with plenty of skins and variety in weapons.Now that I've said something about most of the interesting bits, I'll return to the question at hand. Would I recommend it?No.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I didn't get the hang of the lightsaber fighting mechanics outside of aim at the opponent and hit the attack button, and instead found it more fun to use jedi spells and conventional weapons instead. However, the game punishes you pretty hard for this toward the end of the game when you have to fight through several Jedi. And if you’re like me and skipped out on your "how to fight with lightsaber class", the lightsaber fights seem to randomly decide whether or not you win or die. It got so bad that I didn't even finish the game because the fights stopped being fun to me.The levels are also not that well made. While the game does try to vary it's gameplay by having a different type of objective on each map. The maps themselves are not that memorable had have pretty poor sense of conveyance about them despite, that most of the levels are linearly designed and have one way to reach the goal. Multiple times I got lost because every section looked to similar to each other. Additionally the invisible walls of this game tends to take out some of the platforming fun that could be had as a Jedi.At the end of the day I don't think I will be returning to this game. The fun and memorable experiences I had with it, do not outweigh the frustration I've had with it.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is like the pimple on the face of Star Wars games. I enjoyed it at first but, then this quickly dissolved into a smouldering pool of hatred and frustration. The story is okay, but in terms of Star Wars it's nothing to write home about.  They set it up in the beginning to have some kind of potential but they don't really deliver on it. I know there's a few potential ways for the story to go but after one playthrough I don't really care to explore them. I wouldn't buy this for ten bucks, not even six. This is a purchase I most definitely regret. The gameplay at times is fun and smooth but then it can be clunky, awkward and blood-boiling-break-your-keyboard-in-half annoying.  The variety of force powers is cool and it is the only aspect of the combat that I found enjoyable. However, everything else was just painfully awkward and I tried to avoid the guns and other weapons like the plague during comabt. Overall, I would say you could skip this one. There are plenty of other Star Wars games out there that are much more enjoyable.

Posted: November 19, 2015
												I got this game as part of the Star Wars bundle and I have to admit I never even heard of it before. The entire bundle is great I got more than I even thought I did after trying all of the games. This one is a real treasure! A must have for any star wars fan. If you love the Knights of the old Republic (KOTOR1) following the stories of Revan and the exile Meetra Surik in (KOTOR2) series this will be one of your new favorites. You will meet Jedi Master Luke Skywalker as you embark on a journey to become a Jedi knight. Luke will assign Kyle Katarn (a huge character in the expanded universe) to be your Jedi teacher. This is the last in a series starting with Star Wars Dark Forces where you play as Kyle Katarn before he became a Jedi. Continue through Star Wars Jedi knight Dark Forces 2, Star Wars Jedi knight Mysteries of the Sith, Star Wars Jedi knight 2 Jedi outcast and finally ending with Star wars Jedi knight Jedi academy or play in any order you want. You will not regret buying Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy. I will gladly admit that the Whole Star was bundle is awesome but if you want one of the best star wars games available this one is in my top 5.

Posted: June 2, 2012
												6/10Pros-Fluid fighting system-John williams soundtrack-Good Ai that increases in fighting skill as the game goes on-Awesome Nerdy duels in multiplayer-Lolsy cluster♥♥♥♥s in multiplayerCons-Graphics are somewhat dated-Models are low poly and badly animated-Cutscenes are a cringey pile of skip fodder-Story is dull and uninspiring-Voice acting is cringey-Dialogue is cheesy-Everyone including the enemies lack personality apart from Kyle Katarn who is meagre-The force powers have no imagination behind them to conjure, all you do is push a button, it would have been nice if there was a game aspect where you have to channel your energies and emotions that are subject to the story in order to wield a power more strongly-Linear storyline ,in my opinion this game doesnt qualify as anything but linear, just cos it has a few split hairs right at the very end, doesnt make it non linear, The game just doesnt plant the seeds of evil or good deeply enough in the story to make you believe in your actions, i chose the evil path literally just to see what happens, not because everything that happened previously turned me more hateful. The turns to evil are far too quick and sharp, and so lack any momentum-The jedi training lacks nerdy lore and deep philosophical♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why cant i have a one on one sesh with one of the masters where my mind and body are pushed beyond thier limits and my real ego is laid bare you know ? The one on one training should have been 3/4 of this game, instead of the 0/4 that it was. Get pitched with difficult scenarios, spiritual teachings, field trips to places of magic power, where luke gives us a mystical lecture of how in the end nothing matters and all will perish but our actions live on or some bullcrap like that, Kotor had mountains of that♥♥♥♥♥♥ actually even kotor could have done with more, I literally just want to be turned into a jedi through a video game, thatd be ♥♥♥♥ing epic and its what i expected from a game called "The Jedi academy".Alas it seems i must continue waiting for a deep and dark philosophical journey into the history of the jedi and their spiritual purpose ,at the end of the day it seems this game was made for younger audiences. Posted: September 24, 2014
												+Non linear campaign+Has Kyle Katarn in it+Still has all the great parts of Jedi Knight 2, and takes out all the negatives.+Improves even more on things that weren't problems in Jedi Knight 2.If you haven't played Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast, then either go watch someone play it or go buy it before playing Jedi Academy. They're similar, but to fully appreciate the story and gameplay of this game you should play Jedi Knight 2 first (If you don't want to buy it, both Jedi Knight 2 and Jedi Academy have been open sourced, and you can go find public copies of them now!)If you have played Jedi Knight 2, then basically, this game is very similar to Jedi Knight 2. The general system is the same - you slowly improve your force powers by doing missions and advancing the game. However, you don't have to do the missions in a specific order - you have tiers of missions, and completing a mission allows you to spend one point on a new force power. If you want to be a Dark-side only user, then go ahead! You can do that. There are some "core" force powers (jump, push, pull, etc.) that you cannot spend points on, as these progress with the story.Also, the mods for this game are amazing, and they will only get better since the games have been open sourced.

Posted: December 17, 2013
												The controls for this game are extremely akward and frustrating at times, but that being said, if you like star wars, being a jedi/sith and fps, then this is your game! Graphics are I suppose outdated, but but not without its charm - immerserive enough to not be put off by them. Good level design, relatively big, though you can't revisit levels so limiting to a degree. Very Formulaeic game style in which you start in a window with missions to select (select a mission), then you go on the mission and fight enemies - including very fun lightsaber battles - and then you get a well done and repeat with a concluding mission at the end of each chapter. The game has an RPG element to it where you can increase an ability by 1 per mission. It doesn't really add anything to the game, but it does stop you from completing it in a day! (kind of). The best things about this game compared to Outcast is that you can adapt you lightsaber which effects your battle style - you can also have a dual lightsabre - The other thing is the lightsaber fighting mechanics, which if you like realism, and control, mixes the 2 concepts very well. The fighting is fluid and fun. You can jump off walls (in more than one way) kick your enemy Qui-gon style, and also back stab like Obi-wan. You also get into locked lightsabres where you can push you're enemy, and many things it's just all good fun.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												To this day Jedi Academy is the Jedi-knight-simulator to me alongside Jedi Outcast. It's not like the power-fantasy that the Force Unleashed provides, because it comes from a time when Jedi were more like those in the old trilogy than the prequels. The Force is a powerful... force in this game however, giving you a vast arsenal of both light and dark side powers. You won't be punting ewoks for a thousand yards; the most powerful thing you can do is force-push a missile back at the firer (which is as badass as it sounds). Complementing the Force is an arsenal of guns and your personal lightsaber (single-blade only at the start, with staff and dual being unlocked later). The combat is very fun and often light-saber fights are ended in one or two swings for either side, making them rather intense on higher difficulties. Story-wise you aren't Kyle Katarn, which is a damn shame. You're Jaden, either a man with a feminine name or a woman with a somewhat manly name. Your character is a bit of a blank slate and a dolt, not really a personality to speak of. It's disappointing considering Jedi Outcast has a fairly fun story with a good protagonist. However, the story knows to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up and let the gameplay take over, and besides Rosh being as a git, it's not offensively dull or annoying. It's a classic Star Wars story that shoves Luke Skywalker and Chewbacca in while not really finding its own identity. However, the missions are varied and the general gameplay is such a blast that I find the meh story to be nothing but a nickpick. The mods are godly here, and should be definitely investigated. There's a simple ini mod that allows your lightsaber to cut anyone apart. I'm talking cut them in half, decapitate them, delimb them, force post their lower half into a rancor's mouth kind of cutting. It makes the game probably the best Star Wars game for lightsabers and the death animations actually work well with the mod. Force-throwing your lightsaber and having it decapitate a stormtrooper on it's way back coupled with him falling limply to the ground like that dude in 300 is ♥♥♥♥ing euphoric to me. I still haven't found a better lightsaber simulator.It should be noted that the game has an active vanilla and modded multiplayer community. This mode is horrifically unbalanced in vanilla though. If there's a server with maximum force-powers enable and pits, don't play it. I'll be the unarmed guy force-choking you into pits like a deranged garbageman- abusing the game's targetting to prevent you from doing anything to stop me. Lightsaber free-for-all servers are usually just a gathering of people using power-stance with the force-jump attack or other attacks with wide, extremely damaging hit boxes. There are dual servers that exist alongside free-for-alls, and those are legit fun. Guns are obviously usually useless. The particle-disruptor though is every jedi-killers wet-dream, allowing you to instant kill anyone whose back is turned to you. I'm banned from a few servers because of it.For $10.00 ($20.00 total for Outcast and Academy) I say the Jedi series is a must-have for Star-Wars fans. For anyone else, it's a extremely fun game with varied combat, and is a few hours of fun with a somewhat nonlinear campaign and an active multiplayer community.

Posted: March 14, 2014
												This was the PC game that I used to play while in High School...I couldn't wait until Friday night to just go to town with this classic game.  You see I played the orignal Dark Forces 2 and Jedi Outcast to death  and what I found with Jedi Academy is that they fixed all of the games mechanics from previous games and tweaked the graphics, movement, sound etc..  It still however retained the same classic feel as the other games by utilizing the unreal engine.  Now lets be honest...the single player is crap!  And it will always be crap ever since Dark Forces 2 but where this game really shines is the mutliplayer.  Yes it is very dated compared to some really revolutionary games this year but what makes this game is the breathing community.  It has gone through many transformations ever since its release in 2003 with a sudden over-take of German servers a couple years ago but there are still dedicated clans and players!!  From time to time you may come across some admin abuse but usually they are nice to you if you are nice to them if you respect their rules/regulations. The only real mp modes that are alive now are Free For All and Siege Mode.  Power Duel, Capture the Flag etc.. are pretty much dead town!!  But man this game's multiplayer is what made me a PC gamer in the first place...if you are a Star Wars fan you owe it to yourself to buy this amazing classic game!!  It's so cheap!!  So many memories...gosh I'm even crying a little bit...sniff sniff.  By the way some of community created levels such as Sith Council are some of the reasons this game will continue to be played by countless star wars fans!!

Posted: April 7, 2014
												A must play for Star Wars fans. Picture Force Unleashed but with a less powerful main character (who you can customize), more realistic lightsaber duels, FPS elements, and amazing multiplayer. This game has a good story, good gameplay, and really makes you feel like you are a Force-sensitive learning the ways of the Force and becoming a Jedi (or Sith if you dare). If you love amazing action and a good story then this will probably feel like a slightly dumbed down version of Force Unleased. But while the story and action isn't as big as TFU the gameplay and RPG elements make up for it. 9/10 any day.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												This is dead set one of my favourite star wars game of all time.The story sets you down initially as a jedi apprentice who is (unsurprisingly) "gifted with the force". You get given a set of missions you can complete in any order until you move on to the next set, where each time, you become more and more in tune with your powers. SWJK:JA has some of the best action lightsabre mechanics known to date as everytime you and your opponent attack, your lightsabres will clash until either one of you presents an opening (so expect to do a lot of fun jedi flippy♥♥♥♥♥♥!).Your character customisation is limited although your lightsabre customisation is satisfying as you are allowed to choose your casing, crystal and later on whether you want to weild dual, double or master the single blade. You'll probably find yourself playing through this game more than once for each ending as well (Light side, dark side and "♥♥♥♥ BOTH SIDES I AM THE GREATEST!! SO FEAR ME!!!").Multiplayer is fun if not dead and empty. That said, jedi duals with friends is totally a thing as well as dropping a bunch of bots to indulge the the addictive gameplay.So if the jedi duals in Battlefront II just don't do it for you, and you want something faster paced and a significantly larger amount of backflips than avaliable in KOTOR then this is the game for you!11/$10

Posted: June 2, 2012
												6/10Pros-Fluid fighting system-John williams soundtrack-Good Ai that increases in fighting skill as the game goes on-Awesome Nerdy duels in multiplayer-Lolsy cluster♥♥♥♥s in multiplayerCons-Graphics are somewhat dated-Models are low poly and badly animated-Cutscenes are a cringey pile of skip fodder-Story is dull and uninspiring-Voice acting is cringey-Dialogue is cheesy-Everyone including the enemies lack personality apart from Kyle Katarn who is meagre-The force powers have no imagination behind them to conjure, all you do is push a button, it would have been nice if there was a game aspect where you have to channel your energies and emotions that are subject to the story in order to wield a power more strongly-Linear storyline ,in my opinion this game doesnt qualify as anything but linear, just cos it has a few split hairs right at the very end, doesnt make it non linear, The game just doesnt plant the seeds of evil or good deeply enough in the story to make you believe in your actions, i chose the evil path literally just to see what happens, not because everything that happened previously turned me more hateful. The turns to evil are far too quick and sharp, and so lack any momentum-The jedi training lacks nerdy lore and deep philosophical♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why cant i have a one on one sesh with one of the masters where my mind and body are pushed beyond thier limits and my real ego is laid bare you know ? The one on one training should have been 3/4 of this game, instead of the 0/4 that it was. Get pitched with difficult scenarios, spiritual teachings, field trips to places of magic power, where luke gives us a mystical lecture of how in the end nothing matters and all will perish but our actions live on or some bullcrap like that, Kotor had mountains of that♥♥♥♥♥♥ actually even kotor could have done with more, I literally just want to be turned into a jedi through a video game, thatd be ♥♥♥♥ing epic and its what i expected from a game called "The Jedi academy".Alas it seems i must continue waiting for a deep and dark philosophical journey into the history of the jedi and their spiritual purpose ,at the end of the day it seems this game was made for younger audiences. Nevertheless the fighting is enjoyable and adds much replayability.

You will meet Jedi Master Luke Skywalker as you embark on a journey to become a Jedi knight. Luke will assign Kyle Katarn (a huge character in the expanded universe) to be your Jedi teacher. This is the last in a series starting with Star Wars Dark Forces where you play as Kyle Katarn before he became a Jedi. Continue through Star Wars Jedi knight Dark Forces 2, Star Wars Jedi knight Mysteries of the Sith, Star Wars Jedi knight 2 Jedi outcast and finally ending with Star wars Jedi knight Jedi academy or play in any order you want. You will not regret buying Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy. I will gladly admit that the Whole Star was bundle is awesome but if you want one of the best star wars games available this one is in my top 5.

												Well Well.. Jedi Academy.. First at all, I would say that this is very old game, released in 2003. If any of you asking yourself whether you should buy it or not, know this: 1.) competitive community in this game is very small, check http://www.esl.eu/eu/jkja/ in 1o1 BO3 saber ladder are  only 30 people, it doesn't give any sense to even mention 2o2 ladder. People in "base"  community, which is the basic game without any mods (ja+, lugormod, makermod, Roleplay mod - created by one clan with 1-3 servers), they all know each others because of many years they played together, that's why this game is kinda hard and pretty uncomfortable for potentional novice. 2.) it is a melee game of course, it has strict third person view if u play with lightsaber and changeable view with weapons (on most of the servers you won't meet the guns, forces, only lightsabers - dual akimbo - basically two sabers, staff - darth maul, single saber). 3.) It's hard to say wthether the game is balanced or not, during the years many people argued on this topic, most of them had opinion that staff is too overpowered, very fast with high damage, staffers complained about single blocks etc.. truth is this game had poor development, big potencial, but devs didn't care about this game after release. It is masterpiece and one of the best melee games and most people don't even know about this game, but like any melee game it has its own "bugs", for example: ground butterfly(if u jump back and do a butterfly its grounded with highest dmg), wiggle/poke/spin (if you have some experience with chivalry: medieval warfare, this could be considered as "dragging" but in JK3 it is not deccelerating or accelerating, with poke you are trying to hold your saber in opponent's body with mouse movements as long as you can for highest dmg possible, with wiggle you constantly shake your mouse from left to right also making highest dmg, with spin you just turn your mouse like maniac doing 360's. All this "bugs" were considered noobish or lame in extreme cases even cheating haha, people made their opinion pretty similar to chivalry dragging/delaying, it was in golden era. After many years those "bugs" were transformed in people minds into "techniques", again like in chivalry .. "advanced techniques". 4.) Shame about this game is how people played it during years, how the way of playing this game constantly changed into something disgusting in my opinion. People in years like 2003-2006 or even 2007 relied more on timing and footwork and proper clean killing, nowadays its block festival, those few people who still playing this artifact are just crouching and blockwiggling everything, it looks noobish and disgusting because of thousands ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sparks everywhere, and mainly because block system in this game is highly random. I mean, it is possible to learn how to block, I will explain, opponent is attacking you, you have to aim the way of his saber with your saber and in milisecond when his and your saber make a contact you have to attack. It is very hard to perform and in most cases it is very random, sometimes you do it properly and it won't block.Well to cut a long story short, it might look like this game has more negatives but I would still recommend it, personally I played it since end of 2004  til end of 2013 and ocassionaly play it once for a while because this game is part of my childhood. Yes I would totally recommend this game BUT only for people who seeks for hardcore melee game not looking about graphics, age, activity but strictly only to game mechanics. Be careful, it could be very addictive  ;)P.S.: here are some fragmovies for you, so you can have a better picture how this game was or is played in base community and competitive way and how many possibilities in timing and footwork and way of killing your opponent you can learn

Posted: July 21, 2014
												When I was 6 years old, my sister's boyfriend (now brother-in-law) would bring his xbox over to our house and play games on my sister's TV. I watched him and occasionally played with him. Knowing now how difficult it is to play games with a 6-year-old (I play with his son occasionally), I am surprised he even let me. But I am thankful he did, because playing with him was how I first gained exposure to some of my favorite games of all time. Halo, Elder Scrolls, Fable, and Jedi Academy. I had a lot of fun playing Academy with my brother-in-law, even despite the fact that I was just getting my♥♥♥♥♥beat over and over again. So when I saw it on sale on steam, I couldn't pass up the opportunity to experience it again.This game is everything I remember and more. As a 6-year-old, and again as an 8-year-old when I rented it from the video store, I couldn't really grasp the more complicated aspects of the game, and the story and was confusing. This made it all the more mysterious and intriguing for me. That subtle curiosity that left me both amazed and intimidated by the game has not been lost on me, 10 years later. The aesthetic and atmosphere of this game alone are enough to leave me in awe, but it's the gameplay that really hits home. The lightsaber combat is tight and intuitive. and surprisingly intricate once you delve into its more advanced aspects. The gunplay is similar to that of Quake II, which is understandable, seeing as it's built on the same engine. In today's world of COD and Battlefield and Titanfall and Halo and all that, it's quite refreshing to play a game with straight up skill based arena combat. The mobility is fantastic, with elements of "free-running" that blend flawlessly with the combat. Wallrun, force jump, backflip, and cartwheel your way to victory. Force powers can be taken advantage of as well, with abilities like force heal and force speed coming in handy quite often. All in all, the perfectly balanced amalgamation of melee and ranged combat, fast paced mobility, and usful force abilities makes for a great experience on keyboard and mouse.The multiplayer in Jedi Academy is incredibly addicting. This late in its lifespan, you'd expect a games playerbase to have decayed into a small group of bored kids with cracked clients and a few veteran players on a nostalgia trip. But surprisingly enough, Academy has withstood the test of time, with a solid playerbase of loyal players. The first public server I joined was called the TNA server, which I soon discovered acted as a "home base" of sorts for the long-running TNA Clan. It's a sabers-only server, and players seeking heated battle with competitive yet friendly players, or even just conversation are sure to find a great time on the TNA server. I certainly have. But with capabilities for custom maps, custom gametypes, and even more, the fun doesn't stop at vanilla lightsaber combat. I've come across some fairly interesting things when browsing the server list. A few interesting roleplay servers. a game full of bots that insult eachother with slurs and expletives, even parkour maps. You won't be without something to do when playing Academy multiplayer.I haven't played much of the single-player campaign yet, but what I have played is enjoyable. The story seems enagaging, the voice acting is great (JENNIFER HALE!), and the missions provide a decent challenge, at least on the higher difficulty levels. I would absolutely recommend checking out the singleplayer, but for me, the multiplayer is really where I have the most fun.The visuals of the game are great for their time, and they still hold up well enough as not to distract the player or break immersion. Texture quality is decent, lighting effects are good looking, and even the character models are pretty great for a game from 2003. The game really shines when you incorporate a widescreen fix that allows you to play in full 1080p.So, that's about it for my review of Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy. I loved this game when I was 6, and I love it even more now. I'm sure you will too.10/10, would stumble upon 10 years later and play again.
