Posted: May 7, 2016
												This is a solid older title.Unlike a lot of older titles, the difficulty in this game is actually a bit on the easy side, partly because the AI is braindead but also because your Force Powers are awesomely powerful. You will plow through most enemies once you get a handle on the mechanics, though special enemies that crop up in a couple of missions will require some finesse.Saber combat is this game's highlight. This game came out before QTEs became a standard feature of combat games, but it still manages to feel fluid and satisfying, allowing for a few different fighting styles, from noob-friendly flurries to rapid-swapping between saber stances to catch an opponent off-guard. The saber also reflects blaster shots and is throwable, so it's a very versatile weapon - so versatile that you'll only rarely need to use the other weapons at all.The story is nothing special - it's the typical "stop those dastardly Sith/Imperials from galactic domination" story. There is some character customization but it is primitive by modern standards. The game is structured around five-mission sets of varying style and difficulty (of which you have to do at least four in any order) punctuated by longer, mandatory ones that advance the story. The main plot is a bit hamstrung by this since that means there are only about four plot-advancing missions, but this structure does successfully convey the feeling of the everyday life of a Jedi, taking errands all over the galaxy.Along the way you unlock Force Powers. Not all the Force Powers are equally useful, but there are a few powerful and very fun ones. Fully upgraded Mind Trick allows you to turn an enemy for 30 seconds, Grip allows you to fling enemies into walls or off ledges, Lightning allows you to devastate an entire roomful of baddies at once. Do note that the default key-bindings kind of suck, and I recommend re-binding them to your preference in the control options.The graphics, as expected of an old game, are servicable but unremarkable. The sound design though, is excellent. From the music to the way every weapon and enemy sounds, this SOUNDS like a Star Wars game. And the voice acting is superb all round, including Jennifer Hale for the female Jaden.At only a few dollars on sale, and with a fairly short SP campaign (~12-15 hours) I would say it's at least worth a try!

												This was always my personal favorite from the Jedi Knight Series, though I know it isn't the best. The Force Powers are more diverse than in Jedi Outcast, and I prefered the change in Force progression. Not many weapons were added, but as this was released a couple months after Jedi Outcast, I'm not surprised. The lightsaber mechanics, while unchanged for the most part, were enhanced in that they added dual-saber wielding and double-bladed sabers, adding another level to the complexity of the saber combat. The story progression was also changed from cinematic story progression to level selection. But the biggest change is the fact that Kyle Katarn in not the main character of the story. All of these things depend on your view of the series, but all in all the game is very enjoyable, and definetly one of the top three games in the series (though it takes the number three spot). 8.5 out of 10.

												This was the PC game that I used to play while in High School...I couldn't wait until Friday night to just go to town with this classic game.  You see I played the orignal Dark Forces 2 and Jedi Outcast to death  and what I found with Jedi Academy is that they fixed all of the games mechanics from previous games and tweaked the graphics, movement, sound etc..  It still however retained the same classic feel as the other games by utilizing the unreal engine.  Now lets be honest...the single player is crap!  And it will always be crap ever since Dark Forces 2 but where this game really shines is the mutliplayer.  Yes it is very dated compared to some really revolutionary games this year but what makes this game is the breathing community.  It has gone through many transformations ever since its release in 2003 with a sudden over-take of German servers a couple years ago but there are still dedicated clans and players!!  From time to time you may come across some admin abuse but usually they are nice to you if you are nice to them if you respect their rules/regulations. The only real mp modes that are alive now are Free For All and Siege Mode.  Power Duel, Capture the Flag etc.. are pretty much dead town!!  But man this game's multiplayer is what made me a PC gamer in the first place...if you are a Star Wars fan you owe it to yourself to buy this amazing classic game!!  It's so cheap!! Posted: April 5, 2013
												This is probably the oldest game that I still fire up for multiplayer on occasion (and, yeah, people are still playing it a full decade after its release, if you're curious). It might have my favorite capture the flag of any FPS as the combination of lightsabers, conventional weapons, and force powers add layers of strategy to the game that other FPS' lack. Sure, "Team Fortress 2" CTF probably has more depth over all, but I find it less fun to play, personally, as being stuck in one class can get tiring. Jedi Academy CTF flag is like TF2, only every player has all the benefits of every TF2 class, so your role will be determined by the strategy you employ rather than class selection.On top of this, while the single player is a bit cheesy and no where as good as the previous Jedi Knight games, Jedi Academy is, hands down, the absolute pinnacle of lightsaber combat in a video game. Basically every Star Wars game ever has tried it, but it's distressing how so many have gotten it completely wrong. The last two Jedi Knight games were the only ones to ever nail it: it's fast, fluid, looks awesome, and has just enough complexity to allow for strategic play, but not so much that it becomes an impairment.Anyhow, this rec is meant as a bit of a requiem given that Disney just shut down Lucas Arts for good. This, sadly, means that we probably aren't going to see another "Jedi Knight" game again. However, the shuttering of Lucas Arts allowed Raven to finally release the source code for Jedi Knight 2 and Jedi Academy, so hopefully modders will be able to do some awesome stuff with these games in the near future.

												Ever wondered how it would be to go to the academy and learn how to be a Jedi? Wonder no more! This excellent mix between third person hack-and-slash and first person shooter is set to bring you the story of Jaden Korr, a new Jedi padawan who's going to learn from Kyle Katarn and Luke Skywalker how to be a Jedi Knight.Carry out missions, unravel the mysteries of the Sith, learn to use the Force to your advantage and meet many of the characters from the Star Wars universe we learned to love.A totally must have for any Star Wars fan.

Posted: December 19, 2010
												Saber combat hasn't really been better. Or sword combat for that matter. The missions can be odd, and the shooter gameplay is not great at all, but the saber combat is lovely; it seems semi-random at first when you or your opponents die as a result of random swinging about, but a bit of patience unravels a really rather fantastic and realistic combat system. Multiplayer in particular shines; random waving about is less useful than against the AI and knowing when to time and where to aim combos/forms becomes essential. Some of the better AI Jedi are a lot of fun to fight, as well. It's a real shame the missions pit you against gun users for large portions of the game.The plot is completely silly. If you're here, you're here for the best mechanical Jedi Simulator available.

												This is the greatest Star Wars game of all time. Although this was released back in the early 2000, this game still towers over the rest. You play as jaden; a force sensitive, that joins Luke Skywalkers new Jedi Order. Together with rosh penin you train under Master Kyle Katarn. Posted: February 3, 2014
												This was one of my absolute favourite games in my early teens, so I'm possibly looking at it with rose tinted goggles, but after playing through it again I was extremely pleased to find that it does, in fact, appear to be as good as I remembered it being. The combat is smooth and exciting - getting a chain of force power attacks punctuated by a final light sabre stab is as entertaining today as it was in 2003. It also now has the benefit of modern keyboards and mice, with the extra buttons allowing for a much more fluid use of force powers, now easily accessible at your fingertips rather than awkwardly occupying the function keys.The singleplayer is a fantastic smattering of vastly different mission types that will see you infiltrating, platforming, puzzle solving, piloting, rescuing and investigating. Your force powers grow in strength after each mission, and when you finally get a real taste of freedom it doesn't take long before you feel like the ultimate badass. Unlike many modern games, Jedi Academy actually lets you enjoy this feeling for a few missions before finally ramping up the difficult to an incredibly challenging and fun last third.If you've not played it and want some well-aged action, you could do a lot worse than this. There's also a dedicated and friendly modding community.

Posted: July 24, 2015
												In  STAR WARS™ Jedi Knight - Jedi Academy™, you play as, well whoever you want. The cool thing about this game is that just like the Knights of the Old Republic, you get to choose how your character looks, the problem howevers is that it's left to 3 choices, your head, torso, and legs but along with this you get to customize your own Lightsaber and later on in the game you even get to choose between a double bladed saber or dual lightsabers.  In my review of the story i'll be sticking with the Human Male persona. Star Wars Jedi Academy takes place after Jedi Outcast and for all who haven't played Jedi outcast first why not? Second it's alright becuase you'll be able to understand the story without previous knowledge of the previous games. Story -In this game you play as Jaden, a new student at the Jedi Academy hand picked by luke Skywalker becuase Jaden was able to build a Lightsaber without previous knowledge. While on the ship to the academy he befriends a unlikeable douch named Rosh and then the ship is shot down leaving Jaden to find a way back to the academy with Rosh. After this, Jaden is set on a set of missions to destroy a cult and many other stuff. Each set contains 5 missions were Jaden can upgrade his powers after every other mission with a interlude mission after each set. Gameplay- Jedi Academy is actually pretty much the same gameplay wise with some new things added in. THe lightsaber action in this game just feels so awesome creating some memorable moments when you put up against a army of enemies. Also the force powers in this game in this game just make you feel like a true jedi, especially later on in the game when your powers become really upgraded, It just makes you feel like a badass. To be honest, the main force powers you'll be using is force push, pull, heal, lightning, and sometimes sense. While the other powers aren't horrible, you probrobly won't be using them 'till the end of the game when you just become stacked with enemies upon enemies.Multiplayer- The multiplayer is probrobly one of the best parts about this game. There is still a large community in this game and they are a cool community to. You'll have alot of fun trust me. Also you can play as any playermodel that is in the game or just customize. Overall- this game is in my opionion one of the best star wars games there is being beat by Jedi Outcast. This game has some flaws but they can be over seen with all the awesomness of this game. Overall you should get it.I Grant this game a 8/10 close to a 9/10.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Huge nostalgia trip!When I stumbled across this in steam it brought back a wave of memories , back when I was 11 or 12 and used to play the demo of this game on my dad's computer. I bought it on steam, expecting it to be not as good as a I remembered, as are a lot of my childhood games I go back to. However I was hugely surprised to find it every bit as good as I remembered. Graphics arent half bad given their age, lightsaber combat is fun and fairly varied, force powers are useful and satisfying, maps are well laid out. All in all a pretty decent game. My only complaints are lack of compass or mini map means it often takes ages to figure out where you're meant to be going, and after a while the earlier missions get a tad repetitive, combined with the very slow and sparse story telling. The story/plot is the weakest aspect of the game, but its still great fun for a light saber hacky slashy trip down memory lane.Having just completed both endings I now find myself unwilling to leave the star wars universe just yet, so am presently downloading KOTOR :)Definitely worth a play if you are even vaguely interested in star wars, as I'm not a massive fan but still enjoyed it a lot.Graphics: 7/10Story: 5/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 9/10Replayability: 6:10Overall mark: 8/10

Posted: January 8, 2014
												tl;drYou have a lightsaber and you can stab people with it.Overall, I would proably suggest this game to most poeple.  That being said, it isn't a perfect game, or even great.  It is a good game.  It has weak graphics (even for it's time period), it has a poor story, and the voice acting isn't stellar.  However, it does have character customization, which the previous title did not have.  The weapons in this game are slightly expanded from the last game, and the missions are less linear in nature.The missions are less linear, but most are still required, and many of them have poor mini-plots or stories.  Some of them are more fun than others; the one with the mega-rancor is arguably more difficult than the noghri mission, despite them being on the same 'level.'The character creation is nice; if you ever wanted to play as a rodian.  More to the point, it allows purple or green lightsaber blades, which is much more varied than the previous title (in that one, you got blue).  Your name is fixed (for the purposes of the voice acting) and there's very few options when it comes to choosing the light or the dark side: this is done through the force system.In the force system of the game, you are given eight 'core powers,' which are neither light nor dark.  To make your character light or dark, you choose either light or dark powers for your characters to wield, which in the end doesn't even affect how the game will turn out.  In one of the final missions, there is a choice you must make to show your true allegiance, and this choice is given regardless of light or dark powers.  Choosing different powers mostly just changes your game style, and not by a huge amount.The choice of weapons is similar to the previous title, with a stormtrooper rifle, a crossbow, and a concussion rifle among others.  You'll probably find yourself using your lightsaber against most enemies, though, because it's really effective.  And awesome.Multiplayer isn't too bad, but there's nobody to play against. :(FYI, the default quick-save button is F12, which is kinda annoying if you want to make screenshots.So, if it isn't fabulous, why am I recommending it?  Because it's like, three bucks now.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												Armed with duel lightsabers, I open the door to the next room in the Imperial base. Two storm troopers lying in wait rush me, attempting to flank me. One runs face first into my saber, cutting himself from the top of his forhead to the middle of his chest dying instantly. His friend ran through my other light saber, removing his head from his shoulders. Both men fell lifelessly at my sides while I stood, lightsabers out, unmoving since I opened the door.This game makes you respect the lightsaber in a whole new light. There's a "gore" mod you can download that shows limbs and heads fall of, making your lightsaber a terrifying, grizzly weapon, as a beam sword of pure energy would indeed be. Your lightsaber is so deadly, you dont even need to swing it to kill random storm troopers and thugs, you can simly walk into them with it, or turn your characters body, moving the buzzing beam blade of death into them. Every lightsaber duel with other saber wielders is an action packed game of sudden death. I admit it gets a bit... infuriating when the game decides you get your head sliced off, while your opponent lives from his saber wound to the face and chest... but its the games way of balancing the light saber swings, which I admit are not perfect. For this games time though, its one of the best experiences you could ask for, if you want to feel what its like to be a Jedi. Even modern games like Force Unleashed dont hold a candle to how "Jedi" this game makes you feel, as well as giving the hallowed respect to the lightsaber it deserves.Fun little game quirk, lightsabers remain on for awhile after the death of a Sith or Jedi, resulting in sometimes HILARIOUS death scenes. My favorite so far has been cutting a Siths arm clear off from his shoulder with a downward chop, only to have the inertia from his swing, bring the lightsaber still in his sevared arms hand, down across my neck, decapitating me. XD

Posted: January 6, 2015
												This probably had the best lightsaber physics I have seen in the game. The story is alright but it's climax is very dissapointing. Mostly due to the fact that your character doesn't really have too much of a personality. Also the same 9 songs from the soundtracks of the films repeat over and over. Most of them aren't even the best songs in the films. Expect hearing the imperial march for one second in an admittley very cool level setting for a fan like me. But expect hearing the bespin escape soundtrack 12 times through out the game. Don't expect hearing a climatic song when you defeat the final boss, just a random throwaway song from the films. The appearance customization options are limited but the lightsaber customization is acceptable. You can choose the be a strong jedi all the way, or pull a Darth Vader as you become a fallen angel when you turn to the dark side. And unlike the prequels, the bad side for dilemma makes sense.The level settings vary. The first 6 levels are great, especially the train one, but the later levels get boring and bland. Your stuck in temples and caves for some of the final missions.Overall, it's still a good game. It's the closest I got to making my own epic lightsaber duels.

Posted: June 3, 2015
												It was a little over 10 years ago when I first played this game. This was the game that introduced me to multiplayer, that allowed me to interact with other people and was one of two occasions where I ever joined a Clan. (Shout out to the Free Saber Alliance, if they still exist).This game takes place in the (now non-canon) expanded universe of Star Wars (i.e. after Episode VI Return of the Jedi). You play as Jedi Padawan Jaden Korr who can be human, Twi'lek, Rodian, Kel'dor, male or female. You're a padawan under the tutilage of Jedi Master and former Rebel Agent: Kyle Katarn (from the Dark Forces series of which this is the final entry). Upon (crash) landing at Yavin IV, you are sent on a variety of missions to investigate the presence of a mysterious cult in the galaxy, crossing paths with familiar faces such as Chewbacca and Luke Skywalker.I won't spoil the game but it is advised that you purchase Jedi Knight: Jedi Outcast first and play through it to learn the story. The graphics might be old compared to modern systems but it's still fully playable. The multiplayer still works too and there is a vast selection of mods that you can download and install for the game which can make things a little more entertaining.

Posted: May 19, 2015
												First off, this game is A LOT easier and simpler than the other Jedi Knight/ Dark Forces games. This makes it easy for new players to pick up. The lightsaber combat feels like a real lightsaber, not a glowing baseball bat like in most other Star Wars games. Even boss battles are like that. But occasional glitches, almost unfair enemy and hazard placement plague this game. But it makes up for this by being easily configurable and to modify. (I recommend Movie Duels 2 and Knights of the Force 2.0) A job well done by Lucasarts before the dark times, before Disney. So if you want good, wholesome fun slicing up Imperials, sith, and sometimes jedi, buy this game, it's worth it. P.S. The character Rosh will annoy you to almost your limits, but you can kill him in the Dark Side ending. (Also, if you want realistic saber duels, open console by typing shift+ `, type in helpusobi 1, and then g_saberrealisticcombat 20)

Posted: June 16, 2015
												I bought this game remembering playing it on my original xbox. It was my favourite game.Alas, it brings back all the graet memories and fun from my childhood, bringing with it its amazing combat.The guns? Good, great variety and choices, all lore friendly.The force powers? No force trip, but all of them are good and equal (Except for mind trick in multiplayer).Saber combat? The best saber combat in any star wars franchise game bar none. A mix of jumping and swinging, swinging backwards, rolling and striking, special attacks, throws, and many other forms bring this game's saber combat waaaaaaaaay out of other Star Wars game's league. 10/10 for this game, big time.

Posted: September 17, 2015
												If you're looking for a decent single player star wars experience this is not the game for you.Move on the Jedi Outcase which has an amazing single player campaign with a strong story and fantastic level design.Jedi Acadamy is worth buying for the multiplayer sword duels but that's about it.The single player campaign is formed of lots of small uninspired one shot maps with a loose lame story invented to tie them together. You don't earn your lightsabre, you don't feel invested in what's going on and you don't get that magic star wars vibe.The SP levels are flat and boring with poor lazy mapping and not much fun going on at all. It's a shame as they really did empty the toy box for this one and included Boba Fett, the Rancor and other fan favorites but they're all totally underused and it feels like a box ticking exercise to try and keep fans happy.Multiplayer sabre combat is fun though if that's what you're looking for...

												just beat this game and wow great star wars games make your own character have lots of styles to choose from can be light or dark side with powers if you do every mission for example me i had every light side powered maxed and one dark side power so do every mission plus so familiar faces show up its fun and has aged well it can get a little hard near the end facing two dark jedi at the same time with double ended and duel light sabers but trail and error will beat then just save quick save often and after you are full health and shield but you really feel like a jedi in this game storm troopers will miss you alot if you use speed boost back to back you can clear out 7-15 of them and not get hit once but alot of enemy types and after a while some get repetitive but not to bad cause even so their will still be varity and puzzle solving with force powers plus big levels even though a hand ful look a like but not to much just inside rooms or hall ways game play is light saber and every weapon possible its good to switch up for times you want to lay back and shoot from a distance and just can't run in like a jedi cuz you are wide open so its good in that aspect boss battles are fun some go through the whole stage and dark jedi can only be fought one way but still fun nothing feels better than taking out to sith with one attack and watching the slow motion 360 lol replay value at least one more time cause dark or light side choices and powers i recommend this game if you like old school games or are a fan of star wars other than force unleashed which looks better and plays a little better but this game makes you feel like you are more of a jedi story and cut scenes are ok voice acting can good from good to ok to wtf lol but it works all in all a good time but you will die alot lol quick save before that battle trust me it will save you time and time again lol

Posted: February 4, 2016
												With the die-down of The Force Awakens, most of the fandom and popularity of Star Wars games have died down and faded into obscurity, but not this one. This game is one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played, and should've been the game that EA released. The base game is really fun, with lightsaber combat like you've never seen and a okay story, but most of the people's animations and looks are a bit dated: so this is where Movie Battles came in. Movie battles is one of the best mods for any game ever! It's basically battlefront ON STEROIDS. You can choose Jedi or Sith without a silly powerup, and fight in iconic places all over the Star Wars canon (including EU). I play this game daily, and have fun with it every time...

Posted: February 4, 2016
												Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy is a great game. It takes all the things that made the original good and improves them. you can now wield two sabers or a double saber, there's a bigger focus on lightsaber combat than ever before, but there are problems: the level design still isn't very good, the cutscenes and voice acting aren't very good, and the story isn't very interesting. overall a good game that is worth a try.7.5/10

Posted: May 18, 2015
												This game is like that old sports car you've had and re-bought because it was a 10/10 car (Rx-7) if you're a returning fan from this game.  High quality game play, outstanding graphics for 2003, sword/lightsaber mechanics still out-perform any other game's.  The game is pretty simple to grasp but hard to master on multiplayer.  Yes.  People still play this game online even today.  If you are new to this game and haven't tried multiplayer mode yet, make sure you SHIFT+~ /bind q +button12.  That is a very important console command and will get you very far in life.  Or you know, download ja++ and unzip the files and drag them down to your game data.

												It's a great game to play as a Star Wars fan and I love anything where you can run around with a lightsaber. The gameplay elements are great, RPG aspect excluded which is threadbare at best but it's a FPS game really and the elements you can pick let you enjoy it as you want. Combat is very much 'go with the flow' and the only thing I can really fault is the Jedi Sense power, which comes across as a gimmick rather than sensing anything through the Force.My issue with this game is Kyle Katarn and the fact his involvement becomes so special, the whole reason a final boss wants to squash you is to turn him to the Dark side. Now, I love him in his visual novels and understand he was the protagonist of the last games. As a writer, I have trouble understanding why you would decide to exclude him as the player character because he was too powerful and then centring Jaden Korr’s storyline him. The main character comes off as a distraction at best in their game, and it's quite discordant with the flow of the game.I still recommend buying it as the Star Wars feel, lightsaber, powers and fights are centred through you and the gameplay easily makes up for story weaknesses along with an added multiplayer but this game has limited appeal outside Star Wars fans.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												My purchasing of this game on Steam marks probably the 7th or so time that I've gone through the main game since it came out even though the story itself isn't anything truly remarkable. Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy and the rest of the games in this particular series contain some of the most fun, fluid and frequent lightsaber on lightsaber or lightsaber on stormtrooper action out of any Star Wars games currently on the market. Slow motion lightsaber duel kill cams, Force assisted acrobatics and great level design help blur the lines between gaming and cinematic experiences.  Force pushing enemies off cliffs when they jump to attack you pretty much never gets old. If you need to scratch that itch while waiting for Episode VII, this is one of the best ways to do it, and community-driven and longstanding multiplayer portion of the package will appeal to anyone who is nostalgic for that old-school online gaming experience. I highly recommend this game.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												As 2003's follow-up to Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast, Jedi Academy diverts from the largely-linear narrative of Jedi Knight to bring forth an open-ended, player-controlled experience to the Jedi Knight simulation genre. Rather than playing as the series' main character, the saboteur-turned-Jedi Kyle Katarn, you are his student, Jaden Korr, sent out from Luke Skywalker's Jedi Academy to save the galaxy once more from the dark side of the Force. Featuring a fully customizable main character and a story with two separate endings, Jedi Academy expands upon its predecessor's excellent combat, while at the same time preserving, for the most part, the quality we've come to expect from the Jedi Knight series. If I had to point out my complaints towards this title, I would say that the narrative, while more open to player input, is ultimately slightly trivialized by the departure from series protagonist Kyle Katarn, and, though not nearly as awful as The Force Unleashed, is still a mild letdown after its prequel. In addition, ranged weapons seem to have been downgraded from an alternative form of assault to nigh-useless in this edition, limiting the player effectively to lightsabers, Force Powers, and a variety of combos. Neat? Yes. Ultimately more engaging and fun? Not really. At least give us a buffer between normalcy and Jedihood!Still, if you're at all interested in Star Wars, or you've been playing the Jedi Knight series, or you're even looking for a good action game, there's not much I'd recommend more than Jedi Academy. It's a great ride, and it's a wonderful dose of that galaxy far, far away.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Ah, my old friend. Looking a little older, but no worse for wear.Seriously, this review can be summed up as: BUY NAO!!!Besides some initial trouble in starting up the game on a Windows 7 HP (fixed with this http://lucasforums.com/showthread.php?t=206018), and some graphics hiccups, this game has more than held up well since the last time I played it approx. 5 or 6 years ago. I've played the Dark Forces series since the first game, though I've only beaten the first and this one. This game optimizes the story and gameplay of the previous titles in my opinion, mainly because you start off with a lightsaber but also because the pacing is simply better. The combat is more or less copy+pasted from Outcast, but instead of just being thrown into the mix, you're given an adequately progressive series of missions that, for me, feel tailored to the experience level you should have by the time you reach each one. Note that you receive several missions per chapter, and most are more or less around the same level of difficulty, but some are more unique and require different playstyles to complete.Combat is pretty well optimized, again IMO, for close quarters lightsaber combat. You may think fighting a few blaster-wielding enemies is laughably easy as you one-shot three of them in a row, up until you take a quick glance at your health and shields and realize you need to rethink your decisions. You can clear a room of 5 stormtroopers just to find yourself at 25 HP with 0 shields if you don't pay attention. Then a crimson lightsaber pops up in your peripheral and you find yourself weighing your options.Which brings me to what is without a doubt this game's main draw: lightsaber combat. You'll probably see a few reviews complaining about the one-shot kill ability of it, and while I don't deny it, no review I've read so far has appropriately described it. Every lightsaber battle has felt absolutely rewarding, up to the the multiple "Knight-level" ones you find mid-to-late game. You have just enough offense and defense to hold your own and wear down your opponent, but you can be taken down quickly if you don't take a tactical approach and exploit openings while keeping your distance. It truly hits the right balance of challenge and intuition that many other Star Wars games lack. In short, you want a Jedi Knight/Sith Simulator, you've got one.The only complaint I might have with the end-game/climax. The story is for the most part one of the few I've seen that is most reminiscent of the original trilogy's themes - simple-yet-somehow-deep, cliches and deus ex machina abound yet still engaging. The last chapter of the game, however, gets.....what I can only describe as weirdly campy. I'm a person that likes campy when it's done in the right way, but I was kinda turned off by these particular developments. It's like Episode 1 Phantom Menace Jar Jar Binks in Episode 2 Attack of the Clones campy - imagine his godawful dialogue from the first movie in all the Geonosis scenes. Well, it's probably not as bad as that, but it can be pretty distracting at moments and takes away a little from an otherwise amazing game.WARNING: SPOILERS (And I haven't written enough reviews to know how to black out text). As can be expected from a Star Wars game, towards the end you're faced with a choice between the Light or Dark Side. The choice changes the story up to a point, though you still go to the same locations regardless. The Dark Side choice is harder as you have to fight more enemies, though in my experience it ends up being more fun. However, the campy bits show up in either choice. If you choose Dark Side, your character.........starts yelling. Like, Hayden Chistensen-style yelling, though luckily the voice actor is leagues above him in deliverance, so the questionable dialogue is bearable and even entertaining at points. If you can take Christian Bale's Batman in stride, it shouldn't be a big deal, just be prepared for a sudden character change.In the Light Side portion, the campiness is far worse but doesn't really show until the tail-end of the game, in the 2nd half of a 2-part boss fight. I can't really explain this without SPOILERS: you fight Marka Ragnos. I'm an Old Republic nerd with a Sith fetish and a love of Tales of the Jedi, so his portrayal really made my♥♥♥♥♥itch. Even if you haven't touched a bit of Expanded Universe media, you might find the final boss on the wrong side of cartoonish. When I say that, I mean Scooby Doo villian level cartoonish, complete with "meddling kids" type lines. The dialogue made him sound like he belonged in the Adam West-era Batman. The bad guys can be pretty cliche even up to that point, throughout the whole series if we're being honest, but Ragnos really takes the cake. It kinda feels like the developers just rushed through the last chapter and needed a quick gimmick for each choice section to stand out. If you don't take the game too seriously these bits shouldn't bother you, but they can take away from the immersion for the scenes they're in.Still, it probably says a lot about the game that I can remember it in this detail after half a decade. As of writing this review, I've only played a few missions in the Steam version and it already fits like a glove. Actually it plays better than many of the contempary games I've tried out in the past year. All in all, more than worth the price tag by far. BUY NAO 10/10

Posted: September 4, 2015
												It's much better than Jedi Outcast, they improved almost everything what was wrong with the last game. Now you can choose force powers you want to upgrade and you're lightsaber from three different sabers, also you will get a chance to make choice which side you will turn on story wise and which missions you do first, so the game has some roleplay elements. The best part is that this time you get the lightsaber and force powers right from the start of the game. The level design is much better than Outcast's, so no more strange layout where you get lost easily. The missions are much better constucted than before, as they are compact and intresting, each mission lasts around 30min, only few missions felt like they were too long, the game lasts around 10 hours. The story is interesting and would make a good Star Wars movie by it's own.They still didn't fix the gooey movement which causes you easily to fall to death from high places and makes platform jumping very clumsy. It certainly feels like the movement controls were made for analog sticks, even that the game doesn't support any new game pads directly (maybe some old joystic will work) but you can always use Xpadder, even tho' you won't get the analog stick to work the way it would work on consols.I can recommend this game to Star Wars fans and also other people who enjoy good action game and are not affraid of older games.

Posted: September 17, 2015
												If you're looking for a decent single player star wars experience this is not the game for you.Move on the Jedi Outcase which has an amazing single player campaign with a strong story and fantastic level design.Jedi Acadamy is worth buying for the multiplayer sword duels but that's about it.The single player campaign is formed of lots of small uninspired one shot maps with a loose lame story invented to tie them together. You don't earn your lightsabre, you don't feel invested in what's going on and you don't get that magic star wars vibe.The SP levels are flat and boring with poor lazy mapping and not much fun going on at all. It's a shame as they really did empty the toy box for this one and included Boba Fett, the Rancor and other fan favorites but they're all totally underused and it feels like a box ticking exercise to try and keep fans happy.Multiplayer sabre combat is fun though if that's what you're looking for...

												Single player is a solid story with fun, customizable (lightsaber color and hilt, character appearance) gameplay. An enjoyable experience any Star Wars fan will appreciate that fleshes out the Jedi Academy era of the Star Wars universe. This is a  proper sequel to Jedi Knight 2 and features some of the same characters as well as a plot that builds off of it. The story is linear, but there is flexibility in which levels you play and when. Cool locations and cameos, and more than a fair share of lightsaber duels against single opponents, multiple opponents, or fighting side-by-side with other Jedi Knights.The multiplayer is challenging, with a very sharp learning curve. By this point, the players who are good have been playing for 10+ years. If you are a complete newb to the community, prepare to be brutalized.JK3files.com has a truckload of customizable sounds, music, player models/skins, multiplayer levels, and single player campaigns available for download.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												This was one of my absolute favourite games in my early teens, so I'm possibly looking at it with rose tinted goggles, but after playing through it again I was extremely pleased to find that it does, in fact, appear to be as good as I remembered it being. The combat is smooth and exciting - getting a chain of force power attacks punctuated by a final light sabre stab is as entertaining today as it was in 2003. It also now has the benefit of modern keyboards and mice, with the extra buttons allowing for a much more fluid use of force powers, now easily accessible at your fingertips rather than awkwardly occupying the function keys.The singleplayer is a fantastic smattering of vastly different mission types that will see you infiltrating, platforming, puzzle solving, piloting, rescuing and investigating. Your force powers grow in strength after each mission, and when you finally get a real taste of freedom it doesn't take long before you feel like the ultimate badass. Unlike many modern games, Jedi Academy actually lets you enjoy this feeling for a few missions before finally ramping up the difficult to an incredibly challenging and fun last third.If you've not played it and want some well-aged action, you could do a lot worse than this. There's also a dedicated and friendly modding community.

Posted: September 12, 2012
												In the early 2000s, LucasArts published a couple of truly great games; Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds, the only non-Age of Empires game made on the Genie Engine and Jedi Knight II, the closest you can get to being a real jedi knight.The single player is solid, but if you don't LAN, the game is wasted on you. The multiplayer is diverse, balanced, responsive and a lot more fun than counterstrike or whatever you normally play.There are two iterations of Jedi Knight II. This is the fancy, accessible version.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												This is what I love about Steam. Being able to revisit timeless classics like this at very low cost. This is the game that showed me how great a game could become with such an expansive and creative player community. While the Single Player is great in and of itself the Multi Player is what drives the game and even after 12 years of the games release and coming back to this game thanks to Steam its still as active as ever. As the LucasArts company went under Disney now and the games no longer have the support they once had it seemed that it would kill the game but the original coders released the source code for it to inspire modders to create their own custom content. Just being able to reconnect with my old clanmates, most of whom are in their 20s and 30s now is a blessing. Revisiting the old maps and mods that we all played on and with. All in all this is not only a game of my childhood but one that alot of love was put into both from the playerbase and the old LucasArts team before Disney came along, and my personal favorite in the jedi Knight series. There is a great deal of fun to be had for newcomers and oldcomers alike here and I cannot recommend it more especially as dirt cheap as the game is now.

Posted: March 5, 2015
												After all these years still cool, good controls, reasonable graphics (it aged well) and a cool action packed story. This was my second Star Wars game and it's still awesome, though that might just be nostalgia (played 1 playthrough).Basically the same as 'Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast' in controls, looks and feel only with more RPG like features:This time around you get to choose your character and become a Jedi, starting with a light saber and then developing your force skills along the way. Upon starting a new mission you can choose a new Force power to upgrade (up to 3 points, each level making it stronger) from either the light or dark side. The Core Force Powers (speed, Jump, saberskills and sense [see enemies/items/secrets through walls]) are upgraded within set times between Main-Plot related missions. Along the way you loose your light saber and get to build a new one, but this time you get to choose. 1 LightSaber, Dual-Saber or Saber-Staff. Each Saber has its own unique pro's and con's and Special Moves.All in all a good game, if you can get passed the (rather well) aged graphics!

Posted: August 21, 2014
												This game is the BEST Star Wars game ever made (in my opinion anyway). Story is, you are a Jedi Padawan (called Jaden Korr) who somehow managed to create a ligtsaber without having any prior experience with said tool (lightsaber). On your way to the Yavin IV Jedi Academy with fellow padawan Rosh Penin the shuttle they are traveling gets shot down by Darkside forces. Jaden and Rosh survive the crash and decide to make their way on foot. (Minor spoilers ahead) On their way they encounter stormtoopers and a Dark Jedi (if you thought he was easy... Wait until later in the game). Jaden defeats the stormtrooper and the Dark Jedi, Jaden then sees a women trying to drain the Darkside energy from the Jedi Temple where Jaden and Rosh were supposed to go and train. Jaden then gets knocked unconscious. When he awakes, he is greeted by (the legend) Luke Skywalker and Jedi Master Kyle Katarn. They then fill Jaden in on what happened. You (as Jaden) are then sent on a quest to find out what the Darkside forces are up to. Training under Kyle Katarn. You will meet great foes and allys on your epic adventure through the Galaxy. But what is a Jedi without some awesome force powers and lightsaber tricks to acompany him. You are given loads of force powers to choose from and upgrade, including: Force lighting, force push (and pull) and force jump. For the lightsaber, later in the game you are able to choose a lightsaber fighting style from the one that you already use. You are able to pick between light or heavy style, heavy being slow and powerful while fast is well... The opposite. You will also (even further into the game) be able to pick you own lightsaber. These include: Single Saber (Luke's style of saber), Double Ended Saber (Darth Mauls style of saber) and Duel Sabers (my personal favorite) which is... Well two lightsabers. You can also pick from a veriety of Lightsaber colours and hilts. This game does force and lightsaber combat incredibly well, you really feel the power behind your lightsaber and you force powers. Especially force lighting. So to sum up this game... Buy 70 copies because this game deserves your entire wallet (or purse). Anyway... Have Fun!

Posted: July 21, 2014
												When I was 6 years old, my sister's boyfriend (now brother-in-law) would bring his xbox over to our house and play games on my sister's TV. I watched him and occasionally played with him. Knowing now how difficult it is to play games with a 6-year-old (I play with his son occasionally), I am surprised he even let me. But I am thankful he did, because playing with him was how I first gained exposure to some of my favorite games of all time. Halo, Elder Scrolls, Fable, and Jedi Academy. I had a lot of fun playing Academy with my brother-in-law, even despite the fact that I was just getting my♥♥♥♥♥beat over and over again. So when I saw it on sale on steam, I couldn't pass up the opportunity to experience it again.This game is everything I remember and more. As a 6-year-old, and again as an 8-year-old when I rented it from the video store, I couldn't really grasp the more complicated aspects of the game, and the story and was confusing. This made it all the more mysterious and intriguing for me. That subtle curiosity that left me both amazed and intimidated by the game has not been lost on me, 10 years later. The aesthetic and atmosphere of this game alone are enough to leave me in awe, but it's the gameplay that really hits home. The lightsaber combat is tight and intuitive. and surprisingly intricate once you delve into its more advanced aspects. The gunplay is similar to that of Quake II, which is understandable, seeing as it's built on the same engine. In today's world of COD and Battlefield and Titanfall and Halo and all that, it's quite refreshing to play a game with straight up skill based arena combat. The mobility is fantastic, with elements of "free-running" that blend flawlessly with the combat. Wallrun, force jump, backflip, and cartwheel your way to victory. Force powers can be taken advantage of as well, with abilities like force heal and force speed coming in handy quite often. All in all, the perfectly balanced amalgamation of melee and ranged combat, fast paced mobility, and usful force abilities makes for a great experience on keyboard and mouse.The multiplayer in Jedi Academy is incredibly addicting. This late in its lifespan, you'd expect a games playerbase to have decayed into a small group of bored kids with cracked clients and a few veteran players on a nostalgia trip. But surprisingly enough, Academy has withstood the test of time, with a solid playerbase of loyal players. The first public server I joined was called the TNA server, which I soon discovered acted as a "home base" of sorts for the long-running TNA Clan. It's a sabers-only server, and players seeking heated battle with competitive yet friendly players, or even just conversation are sure to find a great time on the TNA server. I certainly have. But with capabilities for custom maps, custom gametypes, and even more, the fun doesn't stop at vanilla lightsaber combat. I've come across some fairly interesting things when browsing the server list. A few interesting roleplay servers. a game full of bots that insult eachother with slurs and expletives, even parkour maps. You won't be without something to do when playing Academy multiplayer.I haven't played much of the single-player campaign yet, but what I have played is enjoyable. The story seems enagaging, the voice acting is great (JENNIFER HALE!), and the missions provide a decent challenge, at least on the higher difficulty levels. I would absolutely recommend checking out the singleplayer, but for me, the multiplayer is really where I have the most fun.The visuals of the game are great for their time, and they still hold up well enough as not to distract the player or break immersion. Texture quality is decent, lighting effects are good looking, and even the character models are pretty great for a game from 2003. The game really shines when you incorporate a widescreen fix that allows you to play in full 1080p.So, that's about it for my review of Star Wars Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy. I loved this game when I was 6, and I love it even more now. I'm sure you will too.10/10, would stumble upon 10 years later and play again.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												My purchasing of this game on Steam marks probably the 7th or so time that I've gone through the main game since it came out even though the story itself isn't anything truly remarkable. Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy and the rest of the games in this particular series contain some of the most fun, fluid and frequent lightsaber on lightsaber or lightsaber on stormtrooper action out of any Star Wars games currently on the market. Slow motion lightsaber duel kill cams, Force assisted acrobatics and great level design help blur the lines between gaming and cinematic experiences.  Force pushing enemies off cliffs when they jump to attack you pretty much never gets old. If you need to scratch that itch while waiting for Episode VII, this is one of the best ways to do it, and community-driven and longstanding multiplayer portion of the package will appeal to anyone who is nostalgic for that old-school online gaming experience. I highly recommend this game.

Posted: February 19, 2016
												Best lightsaber combat of all time.Story:This game follows your own custom created character on his journey as a jedi. You embark on missions for the academy and unravel a mystery all while learning new force powers and fighting hundreds of enemies across dozens of Star Wars locales. Whether you stay on the path of the jedi, or stray to the dark side is completely up to you.Gameplay: Truly the best lightsaber combat of any Star Wars video game. Simple, yet if you put the time in you can learn all sorts of tricks to fully master it. There are 3 different styles of lightsaber to learn. A single lightsaber with 3 different fighting styles (Light, Medium and Heavy) Two lightsabers (but you can turn one of them off and fight in the single saber light stance) and finally a saber staff, which is a double bladed saber that you can turn one side off and fight in the single saber medium stance.In addition there are also about a dozen other weapons that range from basic blasters to snipers, rocket launchers, and even electric charge guns. And of course it wouldn't be a StarWars game without force powers. Dark Side powers like Choke, Lightning and Drain. Lightside powers like Heal, Mind Trick and Absorb, and neutral powers like push, pull and jump. And so much more.Multiplayer: This game still has a rather large community, and the modding community has already made some fantastic content for this game. Overall:This game is one of my favorite games ever made...I feel like even all these years later it still really holds up. If you like Star Wars, you will really enjoy this game if you haven't played it already.----> 10/10 <----

Posted: June 3, 2015
												It was a little over 10 years ago when I first played this game. This was the game that introduced me to multiplayer, that allowed me to interact with other people and was one of two occasions where I ever joined a Clan. (Shout out to the Free Saber Alliance, if they still exist).This game takes place in the (now non-canon) expanded universe of Star Wars (i.e. after Episode VI Return of the Jedi). You play as Jedi Padawan Jaden Korr who can be human, Twi'lek, Rodian, Kel'dor, male or female. You're a padawan under the tutilage of Jedi Master and former Rebel Agent: Kyle Katarn (from the Dark Forces series of which this is the final entry). Upon (crash) landing at Yavin IV, you are sent on a variety of missions to investigate the presence of a mysterious cult in the galaxy, crossing paths with familiar faces such as Chewbacca and Luke Skywalker.I won't spoil the game but it is advised that you purchase Jedi Knight: Jedi Outcast first and play through it to learn the story. The graphics might be old compared to modern systems but it's still fully playable. The multiplayer still works too and there is a vast selection of mods that you can download and install for the game which can make things a little more entertaining.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Well Well.. Jedi Academy.. First at all, I would say that this is very old game, released in 2003. If any of you asking yourself whether you should buy it or not, know this: 1.) competitive community in this game is very small, check http://www.esl.eu/eu/jkja/ in 1o1 BO3 saber ladder are  only 30 people, it doesn't give any sense to even mention 2o2 ladder. People in "base"  community, which is the basic game without any mods (ja+, lugormod, makermod, Roleplay mod - created by one clan with 1-3 servers), they all know each others because of many years they played together, that's why this game is kinda hard and pretty uncomfortable for potentional novice. 2.) it is a melee game of course, it has strict third person view if u play with lightsaber and changeable view with weapons (on most of the servers you won't meet the guns, forces, only lightsabers - dual akimbo - basically two sabers, staff - darth maul, single saber). 3.) It's hard to say wthether the game is balanced or not, during the years many people argued on this topic, most of them had opinion that staff is too overpowered, very fast with high damage, staffers complained about single blocks etc.. truth is this game had poor development, big potencial, but devs didn't care about this game after release. It is masterpiece and one of the best melee games and most people don't even know about this game, but like any melee game it has its own "bugs", for example: ground butterfly(if u jump back and do a butterfly its grounded with highest dmg), wiggle/poke/spin (if you have some experience with chivalry: medieval warfare, this could be considered as "dragging" but in JK3 it is not deccelerating or accelerating, with poke you are trying to hold your saber in opponent's body with mouse movements as long as you can for highest dmg possible, with wiggle you constantly shake your mouse from left to right also making highest dmg, with spin you just turn your mouse like maniac doing 360's. All this "bugs" were considered noobish or lame in extreme cases even cheating haha, people made their opinion pretty similar to chivalry dragging/delaying, it was in golden era. After many years those "bugs" were transformed in people minds into "techniques", again like in chivalry .. "advanced techniques". 4.) Shame about this game is how people played it during years, how the way of playing this game constantly changed into something disgusting in my opinion. People in years like 2003-2006 or even 2007 relied more on timing and footwork and proper clean killing, nowadays its block festival, those few people who still playing this artifact are just crouching and blockwiggling everything, it looks noobish and disgusting because of thousands ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sparks everywhere, and mainly because block system in this game is highly random. I mean, it is possible to learn how to block, I will explain, opponent is attacking you, you have to aim the way of his saber with your saber and in milisecond when his and your saber make a contact you have to attack. It is very hard to perform and in most cases it is very random, sometimes you do it properly and it won't block.Well to cut a long story short, it might look like this game has more negatives but I would still recommend it, personally I played it since end of 2004  til end of 2013 and ocassionaly play it once for a while because this game is part of my childhood. Yes I would totally recommend this game BUT only for people who seeks for hardcore melee game not looking about graphics, age, activity but strictly only to game mechanics. Be careful, it could be very addictive  ;)P.S.: here are some fragmovies for you, so you can have a better picture how this game was or is played in base community and competitive way and how many possibilities in timing and footwork and way of killing your opponent you can learn

Posted: December 17, 2013
												The controls for this game are extremely akward and frustrating at times, but that being said, if you like star wars, being a jedi/sith and fps, then this is your game! Graphics are I suppose outdated, but but not without its charm - immerserive enough to not be put off by them. Good level design, relatively big, though you can't revisit levels so limiting to a degree. Very Formulaeic game style in which you start in a window with missions to select (select a mission), then you go on the mission and fight enemies - including very fun lightsaber battles - and then you get a well done and repeat with a concluding mission at the end of each chapter. The game has an RPG element to it where you can increase an ability by 1 per mission. It doesn't really add anything to the game, but it does stop you from completing it in a day! (kind of). The best things about this game compared to Outcast is that you can adapt you lightsaber which effects your battle style - you can also have a dual lightsabre - The other thing is the lightsaber fighting mechanics, which if you like realism, and control, mixes the 2 concepts very well. The fighting is fluid and fun. You can jump off walls (in more than one way) kick your enemy Qui-gon style, and also back stab like Obi-wan. You also get into locked lightsabres where you can push you're enemy, and many things it's just all good fun.

Obviously the graphics are a bit dated but that doesn't matter to me if the game is fun.  And putting the darth vader chokehold on stormtroopers and other Imperial scum just never gets old.It takes you around several familiar settings in the Star Wars universe, like Hoth, with  a few characters taken from the movies, like one fight with Boba Fett. Posted: January 16, 2014
												Single player is a solid story with fun, customizable (lightsaber color and hilt, character appearance) gameplay. An enjoyable experience any Star Wars fan will appreciate that fleshes out the Jedi Academy era of the Star Wars universe. This is a  proper sequel to Jedi Knight 2 and features some of the same characters as well as a plot that builds off of it. The story is linear, but there is flexibility in which levels you play and when. Cool locations and cameos, and more than a fair share of lightsaber duels against single opponents, multiple opponents, or fighting side-by-side with other Jedi Knights.The multiplayer is challenging, with a very sharp learning curve. By this point, the players who are good have been playing for 10+ years. If you are a complete newb to the community, prepare to be brutalized.JK3files.com has a truckload of customizable sounds, music, player models/skins, multiplayer levels, and single player campaigns available for download.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												This was one of my absolute favourite games in my early teens, so I'm possibly looking at it with rose tinted goggles, but after playing through it again I was extremely pleased to find that it does, in fact, appear to be as good as I remembered it being. The combat is smooth and exciting - getting a chain of force power attacks punctuated by a final light sabre stab is as entertaining today as it was in 2003. It also now has the benefit of modern keyboards and mice, with the extra buttons allowing for a much more fluid use of force powers, now easily accessible at your fingertips rather than awkwardly occupying the function keys.The singleplayer is a fantastic smattering of vastly different mission types that will see you infiltrating, platforming, puzzle solving, piloting, rescuing and investigating. Your force powers grow in strength after each mission, and when you finally get a real taste of freedom it doesn't take long before you feel like the ultimate badass. Unlike many modern games, Jedi Academy actually lets you enjoy this feeling for a few missions before finally ramping up the difficult to an incredibly challenging and fun last third.If you've not played it and want some well-aged action, you could do a lot worse than this. There's also a dedicated and friendly modding community.

Posted: March 5, 2015
												After all these years still cool, good controls, reasonable graphics (it aged well) and a cool action packed story. This was my second Star Wars game and it's still awesome, though that might just be nostalgia (played 1 playthrough).Basically the same as 'Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast' in controls, looks and feel only with more RPG like features:This time around you get to choose your character and become a Jedi, starting with a light saber and then developing your force skills along the way. Upon starting a new mission you can choose a new Force power to upgrade (up to 3 points, each level making it stronger) from either the light or dark side. The Core Force Powers (speed, Jump, saberskills and sense [see enemies/items/secrets through walls]) are upgraded within set times between Main-Plot related missions. Along the way you loose your light saber and get to build a new one, but this time you get to choose. 1 LightSaber, Dual-Saber or Saber-Staff. Each Saber has its own unique pro's and con's and Special Moves.All in all a good game, if you can get passed the (rather well) aged graphics!

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Armed with duel lightsabers, I open the door to the next room in the Imperial base. Two storm troopers lying in wait rush me, attempting to flank me. One runs face first into my saber, cutting himself from the top of his forhead to the middle of his chest dying instantly. His friend ran through my other light saber, removing his head from his shoulders. Both men fell lifelessly at my sides while I stood, lightsabers out, unmoving since I opened the door.This game makes you respect the lightsaber in a whole new light. There's a "gore" mod you can download that shows limbs and heads fall of, making your lightsaber a terrifying, grizzly weapon, as a beam sword of pure energy would indeed be. Your lightsaber is so deadly, you dont even need to swing it to kill random storm troopers and thugs, you can simly walk into them with it, or turn your characters body, moving the buzzing beam blade of death into them. Every lightsaber duel with other saber wielders is an action packed game of sudden death. I admit it gets a bit... infuriating when the game decides you get your head sliced off, while your opponent lives from his saber wound to the face and chest... but its the games way of balancing the light saber swings, which I admit are not perfect. For this games time though, its one of the best experiences you could ask for, if you want to feel what its like to be a Jedi. Even modern games like Force Unleashed dont hold a candle to how "Jedi" this game makes you feel, as well as giving the hallowed respect to the lightsaber it deserves.Fun little game quirk, lightsabers remain on for awhile after the death of a Sith or Jedi, resulting in sometimes HILARIOUS death scenes. My favorite so far has been cutting a Siths arm clear off from his shoulder with a downward chop, only to have the inertia from his swing, bring the lightsaber still in his sevared arms hand, down across my neck, decapitating me. XD

Posted: February 20, 2014
												So for starters, I didn't grow up with this game. I played it a bit when I was maybe 11 or 12 but never REALLY got into it. I remembered the game being pretty decent and I remembered right, it's pretty decent.So, uh...pros:Lightsabre combat feels good, I really enjoy it, a lot. A LOT. It's not a glowing broom handle, you'll kill a lot of things in one hit, if you don't kill things in one hit you probably just grazed them. There are various guns at your disposal as well, they get the job A combo of cons:The lightsabre combat is good, sometimes to the detriment of the game. If there's a point in the game where the lightsabre is taken away from me for an extended period of time, I'm not a fan. Another scenario being that this is an actio/adventure game, there are non-combat elements such as platforming and puzzle solving. The puzzle solving is touch and go, it's more like go to the place and push the button, very rarely will the game try to totally melt your brains. THE PLATFORMING however, is really imprecise, which can really rain on your parade. blah blahblah end review the game is decent, buy it if you're into it, I don't regret doing so.

Posted: August 4, 2012
												Make sure to enable full dismemberment before you play.  This game is about as violent as games get.  Star Wars game weren't supposed to be this violent, although they should be.  The level of violence is awesome.  You can literally cut people in half with your lightsaber.  You'll have to jump through a hoop or two to get dismemberment working, but it's definitely worth it.The force powers are equally as brutal, as you can use force grip to smash enemies into the wall/ground or throw them hundreds of feet.  The npc models (and your own player model, at times), will look absolutely broken.I cannot recommend this game highly enough (with dismemberment).  The graphics still look good today and there are still people playing online (as of 08.12).  Star Wars hasn't been this good since 1984.

Posted: May 13, 2015
												Long ago I played the demo for Jedi Academy and wrote it off as a cheap cash-in in the wake of Jedi Knight 2, a game I enjoyed but didn't really want more of the same from. Boy was I wrong.Years later I finally get round to playing Jedi Academy and it's surprisingly good fun. A steady supply of varied missions, fun lightsaber combat, and a force powers system that got a satisfying rebalance from JK2: they now recharge faster, upgrade in interesting ways, and are a complete joy to use. Force Lighning in particular is hugely satisfying to use at it's max level: it blasts everything in a forward arc with such intensity it sends people flying off platforms, crashing against walls, and slamming against ceilings. A bit overpowered, but christ is it hilarious.Another interesting quirk of note: this game was made just before the advent of ragdoll physics. Keen to provide some sort of feedback as you slam people around, though, the developers developed a sort of pseudo-ragdoll system that blends animations programmatically to make characters bend (as best they could) with the environment. This makes various storm trooper corpses bend over ledges and objects in an entirely comical way. It's great.

Posted: December 17, 2013
												The controls for this game are extremely akward and frustrating at times, but that being said, if you like star wars, being a jedi/sith and fps, then this is your game! Graphics are I suppose outdated, but but not without its charm - immerserive enough to not be put off by them. Good level design, relatively big, though you can't revisit levels so limiting to a degree. Very Formulaeic game style in which you start in a window with missions to select (select a mission), then you go on the mission and fight enemies - including very fun lightsaber battles - and then you get a well done and repeat with a concluding mission at the end of each chapter. The game has an RPG element to it where you can increase an ability by 1 per mission. It doesn't really add anything to the game, but it does stop you from completing it in a day! (kind of). The best things about this game compared to Outcast is that you can adapt you lightsaber which effects your battle style - you can also have a dual lightsabre - The other thing is the lightsaber fighting mechanics, which if you like realism, and control, mixes the 2 concepts very well. The fighting is fluid and fun. You can jump off walls (in more than one way) kick your enemy Qui-gon style, and also back stab like Obi-wan. You also get into locked lightsabres where you can push you're enemy, and many things it's just all good fun.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												This was always my personal favorite from the Jedi Knight Series, though I know it isn't the best. The Force Powers are more diverse than in Jedi Outcast, and I prefered the change in Force progression. Not many weapons were added, but as this was released a couple months after Jedi Outcast, I'm not surprised. The lightsaber mechanics, while unchanged for the most part, were enhanced in that they added dual-saber wielding and double-bladed sabers, adding another level to the complexity of the saber combat. The story progression was also changed from cinematic story progression to level selection. But the biggest change is the fact that Kyle Katarn in not the main character of the story. All of these things depend on your view of the series, but all in all the game is very enjoyable, and definetly one of the top three games in the series (though it takes the number three spot). 8.5 out of 10.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												The best Jedi Knight game, not because it's the last or anything like that.This game truly is amazing, lots of mods for it like movie battles and KOTF which bring tons of new features to the game making it more fun to play both singleplayer and multiplayer.As for the singleplayer story mode, getting to create your character and start your adventure on becoming a jedi and learning the ways of the force.(SPOILER ALERT!) As well as being able to choose the dark side later on eventually.The game has 3 chapters in total where you can complete 5 missions each to unlock a new one to progress further on and eventually get into an epic boss battle.The multiplayer has lots of gamemodes and ones that are seen in many games such as FFA,TDM,CTF as well as having original ones like Power Duel having to face a sith as a jedi with an npc or with a friend and having to defeat that sith together (Like in Episode 3 Obi-Wan and Anakin Vs Dooku)Setting out on a journey, being in a jedi academy.As a star wars fan why wouldn't you like this? Unless you prefer a different gameplay style of course, though this is definitely a recommendation for all star wars fans who haven't played this and also for non fans!

Posted: April 23, 2014
												I can safely say that the Jedi Knight series is the best star wars games series up until now, forget the fact that the game let's you create your own jedi, the combat feels like a lightsaber fight, each blaster has it's own unique and special abilities making them unique and useful in different situations, this creates a beautiful flow that allows you to be switching constantly in between them leaving you amazed and ready for the next set of stormtroopers to destroy.As you progress through the game, you will get to missions that are clear bright moments in the star wars universe, Tattoine, Hoth, The Rancor, R2d2, every single mission is packed with a fresh style keeping the game unrepetitive as you also complete compelling and demanding objectives that will only leave you wanting for more.Choosing sides, completing missions, recognizing old and new faces, learning the force and the use of the lightsaber, all of this is possible and pausible, always new, always wonderful, till the end.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												This is dead set one of my favourite star wars game of all time.The story sets you down initially as a jedi apprentice who is (unsurprisingly) "gifted with the force". You get given a set of missions you can complete in any order until you move on to the next set, where each time, you become more and more in tune with your powers. SWJK:JA has some of the best action lightsabre mechanics known to date as everytime you and your opponent attack, your lightsabres will clash until either one of you presents an opening (so expect to do a lot of fun jedi flippy♥♥♥♥♥♥!).Your character customisation is limited although your lightsabre customisation is satisfying as you are allowed to choose your casing, crystal and later on whether you want to weild dual, double or master the single blade. You'll probably find yourself playing through this game more than once for each ending as well (Light side, dark side and "♥♥♥♥ BOTH SIDES I AM THE GREATEST!! SO FEAR ME!!!").Multiplayer is fun if not dead and empty. That said, jedi duals with friends is totally a thing as well as dropping a bunch of bots to indulge the the addictive gameplay.So if the jedi duals in Battlefront II just don't do it for you, and you want something faster paced and a significantly larger amount of backflips than avaliable in KOTOR then this is the game for you!11/$10

Posted: March 31, 2015
												This review is only about single playing (campaign mode). This is a decent FPS, but no more than that. Don't expect it to be as good as Quake or Half Life. AI is quite mediocre; some troopers will remain standing still after you hit them if you are not close enough. Level design could have been better. There are levels where you get bored roaming around and there are others with pretty cool twists (vehicles, creatures, etc.).In a nutshell, if you are into Star Wars, you will probably enjoy the game. If you are not, I'd recommend looking for a better FPS. Since most people like Star Wars and the game is quite cheap by now, overall I recommend it.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												Compared to the xbox original version what i played this game hasnt changed, it is a fantastic port.The mission concept is good, the fact that through a replay if i can't be botherd with part of the stage, then i can come back 4 levels later with more powers. The Combat is tricky, using a gun will hit your enemy almost always, run at them with your lightsaber or even standning next to them and you can miss, just for moving your mouse slightly. Frustrating as it may be, you left click rappidly a few times to and not miss again and end up pulling offf a great combo...which you'll never see again until your next miss.The enviroments are that of other games, but extended to areas we havn't seen.Now force powers! Choosing dark or light doesnt really matter, it plays more similar to that of a human in our world, it doesn't matter what powers you use (just a few minor changes in dialouge) , it's how you use them. Do you use them for good or for evil? Force drain i don't really reccomend, it uses up force power instantly, yes you can over heal with them but it's not really that damaged, plus whlst you use it you are fully open to attacks. Force heal can be leveled to eventually use in combat, The jump in this game is more tomb raider , but i find it to be the closest force jump to that of the films. I feel compelled to play this game though, as all star wars games before and after. Overall it's a great play and replay, many times over ~You're just a padawan, you can't use your lightsaber..... at the endgame your a master, and you're lightsaber uses you

Posted: October 20, 2014
												This game isn't bad at all, just not as good as you'd think. The story feels like a fan fiction, and Lightsaber vs Lightsaber fights are the worst part of the game. Basically it's click-click-click and hope the game lets you kill the enemy, especially on high difficulties, there's no depth or strategy except hope you can use force grip and drop them in a pit or, again, hope the game lets you kill them before they instantly kill you. But I recommend this game because it's still fun. killing groups of thugs and storm troopers never gets old. It's also an old school 3d platformer in alot of stages. And I love a few levels that mix things up, like the swoop bike level.If you're a hardcore Star Wars gamer, go for it. Kyle Katarn is awesome and he's your master. Else I'd find another game if you're not into star wars.

												Probably one of the best Star Wars videogames! Posted: February 19, 2016
												Best lightsaber combat of all time.Story:This game follows your own custom created character on his journey as a jedi. You embark on missions for the academy and unravel a mystery all while learning new force powers and fighting hundreds of enemies across dozens of Star Wars locales. Whether you stay on the path of the jedi, or stray to the dark side is completely up to you.Gameplay: Truly the best lightsaber combat of any Star Wars video game. Simple, yet if you put the time in you can learn all sorts of tricks to fully master it. There are 3 different styles of lightsaber to learn. A single lightsaber with 3 different fighting styles (Light, Medium and Heavy) Two lightsabers (but you can turn one of them off and fight in the single saber light stance) and finally a saber staff, which is a double bladed saber that you can turn one side off and fight in the single saber medium stance.In addition there are also about a dozen other weapons that range from basic blasters to snipers, rocket launchers, and even electric charge guns. And of course it wouldn't be a StarWars game without force powers. Dark Side powers like Choke, Lightning and Drain. Lightside powers like Heal, Mind Trick and Absorb, and neutral powers like push, pull and jump. And so much more.Multiplayer: This game still has a rather large community, and the modding community has already made some fantastic content for this game. Overall:This game is one of my favorite games ever made...I feel like even all these years later it still really holds up. If you like Star Wars, you will really enjoy this game if you haven't played it already.----> 10/10 <----

Posted: May 5, 2014
												This is the best Star Wars game I've ever played. In fact, this game has the best combat out of any game I've ever played. Despite this game's age, if you enable it with the mods called OpenJK (Maintenance of the base game by the community) and JA++ (Enables advanced server controls, some fixes, new animations and moves), the game plays amazingly well and even looks decent.
